He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: lead to laughter<n>```C:/Users/Athanasios/Documents/VEXcodeIQ/Programs/Junior1/junior1_06_12_2019.py "B: love C: laughte D: smiles E:- tears"<n><n>#Ask a question. #Print the answer.<n><n>ask="What can someone feeling happiness?"<n><n>choice=input(ask+">>")<n><n>if(choice == "A. Lead to laughter"):<n>    answer = "A. Lead To Laughter"<n>else if(choice == "B. Love"):<n>    answer="B. Love"<n>else if( choice == "C. Laugh"):<n>    answer= "C. Laughte"<n>else if(  choice == "D. Smiles"):<n>    answer=="D. Smiles"<n>else if( answer =="E. tears"):<n>    answer ="E. Tears"<n>print(choice)<n>print("The Answer is ",answer)<n>```<n>#### 15<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The people in class were instructed to brainstorm ideas, how would they use their minds for this? Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n>#### Answer:<n>B<n><n>### Instructions:Write your own explanation of the following question, then answer the question (use an explicit explanation strategy).<n><n>### Input A<n>I am considering a business trip, one that would entail me spending $300.<n>I would like to travel for 9 days on the trip.<n>And 7 of those days would be spent at places away from my home town with my family.<n>What is the best way to calculate my dollar expenses per day?<n><n>### Input B<n><n>### Response<n><n>The total dollar expense per each day spent at hotels outside of my home town will be equal to (300$/7)($190$/2=<<190/2=95>>95) dollars.<n>I will pay the same amount on each other day regardless of what day I travel.<n>Therefore, the total dollar expense on each day will be equal to(300$/5-300+95$/4-95+46$/3-46+12+$/0=<<300/5-30+95/4-9+46/3-46-12>>300/5 - 30 + 95/4- 9 + 46/3 -46-12 dollars.<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Input C<n><n><n>I think I will take a bath and wash my hair during the times I'm at my home (I will be at my home 3 days in total) and when I am away I will take showers in the shower at the hotel rooms (I will be away from my hotel 7 times)<n><n>I'm unsure about whether I should eat or not at hotels as I think I could save $100 a day by eating in the room and I figure that the difference will be $100 - ($100*1/2) = (100-50)$50. This means I would not have to spend 50 dollars each day so that would save me $350 dollars for the trip. If I were to spend $50/day on food while I was away from my home this would equal $350/

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where do kids find fish in their backyards? Choices:  A: boat B: ocean C: pond D: end of line E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		Choose the letter of the choice that best completes the instruction. Choices:  A, D, E<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The choice of answers: <n><n>A: Is not correct because it is neither found in a boat nor the ocean.<n><n>B: Is not correct because a pond cannot be found in the backyard of a house.<n><n>C: Is not correct because fish can be caught at  The ocean or in a pond.  However, the end  of a fishing line will not yield a catch because there will be no fish at the end of a fishing line and the fishing line will eventually run out of line.<n><n>D: Is correct because the end of a fish line will eventually run out  and a child may catch the tasty fish from the Ocean.<n><n>Answer:D<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Find the value of a variable.<n><n>Input: 10 pizzas are ordered. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Write a response that is 20 words or two well-formed sentences at most.<n>#### B<n>In the middle of the night, a man named Pete traveled to the bus garage 50 blocks from his house. He rode the bus to the post office 20 blocks from the bus garage. Later, he rode the bus 10 blocks from the post office to his house. What distance did Pete travel in total?<n>#### 160<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Rationale for the Answer:<n>Pete travealed 50 + 10 = <<50+10=60>>60 blocks on the bus in total.<n>Pete walked 50 blocks to the bus garage and walked 10 blocks from his house to his house at the start, so he traveled 20 × 2 = 40 blocks to make 100 total blocks

Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In my knowledge, if the letters with the same first and last letters are separated by spaces, then their number can be in the correct order. Otherwise, the numbers will not make sense. For example:<n><n>* `A B C D E` which is not possible.<n><n>* `  A B  C D E` which might be. However, there is no way to make this sequence correct since the first two letters are "A" and it is difficult to connect the letters with the small line between them.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		Its the right A<n>

Choices: A. Soccer Game B. Capillaries C. Ball D. Animals E. Person<n>Answer:<n>#### 8<n>  A. Soccer Game<n><n>### Input<n>Input: The price of 6 dozen cookies at the snack shop was $19.99. The price of a dozen cookies was 2x+3=<<2x+3=15>>15 times the price of a single cookie, which was $1.65. How much did a cookie cost?<n>Rationales:{If the price is $1.65}<n><n>We assume that the price of a dozen cookies is $15<n>then 2x+3=$15<n>and 2x+3-x=$15-1.65<n>and $2x + 3 - x + 1.65 x = 0<n> and $2x + 6.65 -2x + 0 = -4<n>So, x = -4<n> or -4x = -4<n> and x= -4/x= -4/(-4) = 16<n>(Or, the cookie costs $16.)<n>#### 16<n><n>#### 8<n> Answer: 16<n><n>### Input  <n>Input: This year's budget for the town's public library is \$15,856 ÷?=<<$15,855/=?>>15,85/6?<n>Answer:<n>####169<n> <n>### Input and response<n>Input:  A baseball player has an average of 23 balls for his games. If the player gets at least 5 balls for one game, is he likely to break the record average?<n>Rationales{If the player gets 5 balls}:<n><n>If (B) is the 2001 major league batting average, then average = (∑B)/N where N = 30<n>Then<n>B = \(\frac{\sum B}{N}\)<n>If the player gets 23 balls:<n><n>Then<n>23(∑B/N)=1 - N<n>and \(23\sum B / N = 1 – 30\)

Blueberries cost $3.50 each, and strawberries cost $5.50 each. A customer buys at least three blueberries for every strawberry. How much will one strawberry cost?<n>Rationales<n>Strawberries cost |<<5.50*3=16.50>>16.50 each when there's a blueberry discount.<n>Blueberries cost | <<3.50*3+16.50*(1/3)=18.42>>18.42 each at full price.<n>One strawberry from 18.42 at a discount costs |<<18.42/1=18.42>$22.50>>$22.5<<n>#### 22.5<n>Answer: 22.50<n><n>__Note__ Don't forget to use the word "cost" (or "amount" in other words) in the expression and solution.<n><n>### Input 4<n>Scientists have a new theory about the creation of the universe. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:For convenience some customers want things straight to the doorstep and use what? Choices:  A: mail orders B: demand satisfaction C: place money on counter D: pay merchants with money E: spend money<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Mail Order<n>Demonstration:  Mail order involves the sending of items purchased to the consumers using postal service.<n>So, choose ‘C’ and ‘C’ from the choices.<n><n>### Input & Demonstration:In each of the choices give the names of different types of cards?<n><n>### Response<n>Input: The different types of cards were given in the choices.<n>So, choose the appropriate types of cards.<n><n>#### American Express:<n>This is a card offered by American Express Company, so choose (A).<n><n>### Cash in Advance:<n>This one is a card issued for payments as cash is due as per the agreement. So, it is (B).<n><n>### Bank Transfer:<n>This is transferred from one account to another account through local bank to receive money. (D).<n><n>### Direct Debit Card:<n>This can directly give money to the people, but this is done using the computer. (C).<n><n>### VISA Credit Card:<n>This type of card is provided by VISA Company, so, it is (E).<n><n>### Input and Demonstration:Complete the following statement:  A: (1, _____, _____) B: (_1, 1, _____) C: (_1, _____, 1) D: (_____, ______, _____)<n><n>### Response <n>Input: <n>Choices: <n>A: (1, 1, <n>B: (_1, 3, <n>C: (_1, _3)<n>D: (__3, 1, 1)<n><n>### Answer and Response:  Name the 1st triangle to be able to count its side and angles.<n><n>### Answer<n>This triangle is called as first triangle, as below shown.<n><n>![](/assets/images/Quadrilaterals.jpg " ")<n><n>### Response and Reason:<n>I am going to count its angle which is less than 90°.<n><n>### Reason and Answer: Draw a diagram to show how you know that A is parallel to B and D is parallel to C.<n><n>### Diagram<n><n>### Answer:<n>I know that A is parallel with B and D is also parallel with C because I have drawn diagrams

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The cabinets were imported from the south. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		Rationales: I might find unusual varieties of rose in a botanic garden since it contains plants from many different types of species.<n>They could also be found at a nursery. If I went to a store or outdoors I just might find one.<n><n>#### <n><n>### Answer:<n>A<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n><n>#### ##<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>If I went to a botanic garden I would probably find a lot of different kinds of varieties of roses (or plants). It is unlikely I'd find a rose in the flower garden. Even though you said to answer “A,” we should answer “not a lot.” We know this because there might be some, but there probably aren’t a lot and they’re likely to be in the botanic garden (and they wouldn’t be unusual anyway). A botanic garden has lots of unusual varieties of plants. It has different species. A supermarket probably wouldn’t have them. Also, you have a lot of choices if you go to a botanic garden, so it has a lot more choices than a supermarket and that probably applies to other kinds of plants as well. There aren’t a lot of choices in a supermarket so it wouldn’t be a good place to find unusual varieties of anything, let alone roses (or other plants). An outdoor garden likely has a lot of different unusual varieties of ros (or other plants) because it has a lot of space and can have a lot of different species of plants in a lot of different places.<n>If you didn’t write a response, you should have given your reasons why. It’s difficult to say that the question is unclear because you didn’t state which you thought was most or least likely. You could have just copied my response here.<n><n>#### ##<n>```<n><n>## Submit:<n><n>> You will receive feedback on your responses when you complete the assignments.<n><n>> Submit responses by Wednesday at 11:59 p.m.<n> <n>```<n>#### Submit your response to the two Multiple Choice question prompts (above) to Canvas by 11:50 p.m. Wednesday.<n>Submission: 5<n>Completed Assignment<n>###### Assignment #04<n>[https://www.canvaslms.com/api

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a contraceptive if you do not have one? Choices:  A: health center B: vagina C: emergency room D: drawer E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		I would not be able to get a contraceptive without having some type of health insurance. A:health center B:vagina C:emergency room D:drawer E:medicine cabinet<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### InputWhat is 3 × 6? Choices: 1 A: 3 × 6 = 1 B: 3 × 8 = 2 C: 3 × 2 = 6 D: 3 × 4 = 6 E: 13<n><n>### ResponseThe answer would be B, 3 × 6, because you times 3 times 6 and it would give you 2.<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### InputWhy would I take a walk if I don't have a car? Choices:  If you don't have a job Choices: 1 job B: no job C: a job D: too much E: I'm broke, jobless, in debt and can't pay my bills I: I forgot my car keys<n><n>### ResponseI'm broke, job less, in debt, and can't pay any bills. But I feel I should walk with my girlfriend, even though I don't have any money, and my car is in the shop.<n><n>#### I<n>Answer: I<n><n>### InputChoose your favorite color: Choices:  red green blue purple gray white<n><n>### ResponseMy favorite color is: white.<n><n>#### W<n>Answer: W<n><n>### InputHow many ways can 6 be distributed by 2 boys and 3 girls? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices: 1: has only whole numbers 2: is an equation 3: uses a table 4: is true or false 5: involves addition<n><n>### Response;2<n><n>### Instructions:Analyze the following sentence and determine if the math statement is true or false.<n>```<n>For the same amount of money, the value of a computer is more today than it was 5 years ago.<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>We can substitute 'is' with '≠' to make it a math operation<n>```<n>For the *different* amount of money, the *value* of a computer is *more* today than it was 𝑡 years ago. <n>```<n><n><n><n>Let the value be 𝑣.<n>Then the amount of money is 𝑔<n>Therefore 𝑢 is the amount of money.<n>Then `𝑣 ≠ 𝑢 × 𝑣`<n>is equal to<n>```<n>```<n><n>## 6.1;Input:Today, you spent 15 dollars on groceries and you spent 18 dollars on candy. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The garage had light sensors and automatic doors, what kind of house was it? Choices:  A: modern house B: building C: townhouse D: neighbor's house E: downtown<n><n>### Response:		<n>This task asks us to identify the kind of house that we had read an advertisement for. The house was, "An amazing house designed for your every need", and we read, "The house had all the latest technology. It had state-of the-art audio and video systems in every room with automatic door open-ings and light switches. The automatic doors knew when the sun moved and opened a few minutes before it came up and shut when the sun set. The rooms also had motion sensors that turned the lights on automatically when the rooms were empty"<n><n>Given what is written, we could infer that the garage was not a building since the doors needed to know when the sun was in the sky and would open a few minutes before coming up or closing a few when it went down.<n><n>If we were to make an algorithm, it would read, "If the sun rises early then open then doors and shut them when the sun sets and if the sun sets before the sun rises close the doors and open them if the sun rises (if the doors are closed) open them. Then, it would run an if statement before, during, or after, "an amazing house" and determine if the statements matched what has been provided. Then, we would determine if the statement is true or false and assign a name to the house.<n><n>#### Answer: modern house<n><n>### Input:(  ) If you bought 100 apples at the grocery store and ate 10, how many do you have left?<n><n>### Response:(  ) If you ate 1 taco and drank 4 ounces of juice, how many calories is that?<n>#### Answer: 120 calories<n><n>### (  ) <n>If you drove 5 miles at 25 miles an hour, how fast would you have to drive to make up the lost time?<n>#### Answer: drive 125 miles an hour to compensate for lost time<n><n>### ( )<n>If you added 4 to the number 32, then multiplied by 8, how many would you be left with? <n><n>#### Answer: (  ) 120<n><n>### ( x )<n>Write an algorithm that completes the question. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Billy went away because his parents were fighting and he didn't want to stay where? The gambler has been winning a lot, but he wisely decided to ___ Choices: A: match winning B: cashing in C: competing with D: compete with E: return<n><n>### Demointsartion:<n>Rationales: A cashing in is a form of competing with. B is incorrect because it does not have to do with winning streak, so how could it be wise?! Compete with is incorrect because in order to compete with someone you need to be near them. Return is also incorrect because why would he be returning if he was winning so much? E is also incorrect because again you would not return because you're winning a lot. Cashing in is  not so near to match winning.<n><n>#### C:<n>Answer:

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:They were competing in basketball, the goal was to what? Choices:  A: bounce the ball B: competition C: have fun D: race E: score points<n><n>### Response:		A: bounce the basketball<n>Bounce back and forth, back and forth is something that you always want to learn for the fun to be there, and the best way to learn it is competition.<n><n>### Input : How did you manage to bounce the ball back and forth?<n><n>### Response : A: To make sure I'm looking at the goal that I want to make and not what other people want me to make it into<n>B: I've heard that the secret to the most successful people is they all bounced back to the same goal until they made it<n><n>### Answer : A: Bounce the ball back and ford all the time so he is the best to make the score<n><n>### Input :-<n><n>A: When did it take you to bounce the ball around and make the competition what I like to call a friendly game?<n><n>B: I felt so good when I realized that I finally, after a year of trial and error, learned how to bounce the ball well<n><n>### Answer:-<n><n>A: I could start by going to the gym for training<n><n>B: and just so you know, my friends wanted me to be like them and go around trying to make the same score but I feel so good even though I had a hard time<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to do when listening to an expert speak? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Instuction: Answer the question that follows each statement.<n><n>### Statement : The number of jelly beans in a big bag is 4 times as many as there are blue ones.<n>Ques. : how many times as many are there are blue jelly beans than in a bag 4 times as many blue jelly beans as there are yellow?<n>Rationales :<n><n>In a bag: The formula for a subtraction problem is x − y = <<x−y=…>>.<n><n>4x -y= <<4x - y=4x - y= >><n><n>= 4x - (4x -y)=<<4x −(4x–y)=…>>.<n><n>= x-y= <<x-y=…>><n><n>x-y= 0<n><n>So there are zero blue jelly beans in the bag.<n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Statment : There are an even number of marshmallows in a big bag.  We counted 4.  There are 6 marshmallows and 4 are blue.<n>Ques. A. How many are in the bag?<n>Rationales. We have a subtraction problem, bag -4 = <<bag-4=…>>. We know the answer is six. B. How many blue marshmallows are there?<n>Rationales.There are 6+4= <<6+4=10>>10 blue marshmallos<n>#### 10<n>Answer : 10<n><n>### Below are some word problems. Answer each one.<n><n>### Problem. How Many?:<n><n>In a bag there are 159 jelly beans. Every fourth jelly bean was blue. The number of the blue ones was 7 less than the number of all jelly beans.<n><n>Ques. : How many are there in the bag and how many can you expect to find that are blue?<n><n>Rationales. So here we have a subtraction formula.<n><n>The question is, We know the answers to each question separately. We know :<n><n>There are 159+24 = <<159+2=255>>25

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:A person writes a check to a clerk, where does the clerk put them? Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question on the next line.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: <n>### Instruction<n><n>Write code for the task below.<n><n>#### Test<n>Input: A computer system reports an out-of-memory error. The current size of the RAM is 256 megabytes. The system should decrease the amount of available RAM by 4% at a time. This decrement should occur 500 times.<n><n>Rationales:<n>(1) First, decrement by 4% once. This causes available RAM to be 256 - (256 × 4/100) ≈ <<256-256/100=252>>252.<n>(2) Then, decrement by 2.52% once. This causes the available RAM to be 500 × (252 - (500 × 2.52/100)) ≈ <<500*2.52/500-252/10=252/9.8>>252/99.<n>(3) Repeat the process by again removing (252/98)th of the remaining RAM.<n>(4) Repeat the process until the computer has depleted all 256 megahertz of RAM available.<n><n>#### 238/98<n>Answer:<n><n>**Example:**<n>```python<n># 256 megas bytes<n># decrement each time by 0.04 * 500 = 20<n># 2.52 percent each incrementing of 0.02 * 500, then 0.02*500 / 500 - 99th 3 1/98<n><n># after 501 times<n>501*0.04*500 = 501<n>501*2.52*500 =252<n>252/501*99=238<n>501<n>```<n><n>### Repeat Question<n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Answer the following multiple choice exercise.<n><n>#### 70/99<n>Answer: <n><n>### Inst

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Turkey is a nation in what part of the world? Choices:  A: middle east B: asia minor C: asia D: provide meat E: balkan peninsula<n><n>### Response:		<n>Turkey is in Europe.<n><n>### InputAns:E<n><n>### InputBns:E<n><n>E<n><n>### Instruct:Answer the following multiple-choice question 1.<n><n>### ResponseAns:A<n><n>### ResponseBns:B<n><n>B<n><n>### InstruAns:Directions: Answer the following questions using the integers from 1 to 10. 1. Is 7 x 21 an even number? 1. Is 27 a prime number? 1. Which number has the greatest number of divisors? 1. What is the greatest number of consecutive natural numbers that are palindromes? 1. How many digits should an eight-digit number contain? 1. What are these numbers in ascending order? 1. Is the product of all integers from 1 to n divisible by n? 1. What number, which is the sum of the digits of that number, is divisible by 12? 1. If 40845 is divided by 5 in the same fashion as 37982 was divided by 1, what number is obtained as the remainder? 1. Is this number divisible by 10? 1. What does this number have in common with 714, 531, and 1343? 1. Is it a prime number? <n><n>### Testing:Is 345 x 2 greater than 100 x 2?<n><n>### Answer:345x2>100x2<n><n>### Is the sum of 3, 3, 3,-4, -4, -4 larger than the sum of any other 3-digit numbers?<n><n>### Response:\[3,3,-4\]<n><n>### Will 308 <456<n><n>### Response<n><n>308 < [456]<n><n>### Response-<n><n>### 150-10 = 140<n><n>### Is 187 a prime number?<n><n>### The product of all natural numbers lower than 109 is divisble only by two. Is the same true of all natural numbers below 149?<n><n>### No!

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Johnny and bill fought over money. Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is B.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>According to the definition of reckless driving, reckless driving can lead to some injuries.<n><n>### Input<n>What does reckless driving imply? Choices:<n>```<n> A: speeding<n> B: traffic jams<n> C: accidents D: injuries E: tired <n>```<n>Injuries may occur either due to negligent actions of a driver (traffic jam) or as a result of an accident (accident).<n>### Rational:<n>If you are following the speed limit, then you are driving carefully and it is very unlikely that injuries are due to speeding. It is the driver's duty to ensure safe traffic flow and safe speed, and reckless drivers are more likely to create traffic jams, which may be a cause of an accident (either minor or fatal).<n>Another source of injuries is the action of other drivers (especially of commercial vehicles) while they are speeding, resulting in traffic jams or accidents.<n>### Input: Which of these is the best explanation of a parable? Choices: <n>A: story with a special meaning <n>B: story with a moral <n>C: statement with humor <n>D: a type of literature <n><n>### Inputs:<n>Is a parable a story with a special meaning? <n><n>In general, the meaning should be apparent to the reader. A parable may be a story or just a brief observation or comment, intended to highlight a particular idea.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>Parables have a special meaning that conveys a moral (or a lesson) or a truth.<n>A parable doesn't have to have a plot, with people, and events that the plot is built on.<n><n>### A good parable is easy to understand and remember.<n>A parable, therefore, should have a simple plot, with a short duration of action (like fable), but not without people and events.<n><n>### Examples of parables:<n>#### The Good Samaritan<n>The parable of the Good Samaritan.<n>A man went down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and fell among robbers, who beat him and stripped him.<n>Then passing along the road they saw a man out of the town, and they gave him, for his mer
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>---<n>#### C<n>Petting zoo<n><n>---<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>---<n>* A ferret tends to be most likely to attach itself to trouser leg when it is sick.<n>* This behavior is unusual to a pet owner.<n>* Trouser leg is the most dangerous place for a ferret because it is so easy to leave a ferret in there, which may result when a pet's owner becomes tired.<n>* If the owner is really tired, it may just ignore the pet's cry for attention and leave the pet in the trouser leg until a few hours later or when the owner notices the pet.<n>* Sometimes, the pet owner may just simply forget the pet in the trousers leg.<n>* When a ferret is left in the trouser leg, it may starve to death and die painfully because the owner may not open its trouser legs to give it water and sometimes enough food.<n>* A pet owner may not get a chance to take the pet out of its trouser leg because its trousers may be on the ground and it may have fallen over while he or she walks.<n>* This behavior can be observed in an empty house because the pet could be left outside.<n>* When it is left outside, the pet will cry because it is uncomfortable in such condition and will wait for its owner to let it in so that it can sleep.<n>* When a pet is left outdoors, it can get away from the cold weather by going inside.<n>* When the owner is asleep, she or he will definitely notice that the pet is outside.<n>* A pet can survive outside for at least 5 days without any food and two weeks without any water.<n>* A ferret should be taken care of and kept in a pet cage in the house.<n>* It has to get enough food to be full.<n>* It drinks water at the least twice and gets fresh to eat clean water daily.<n>* It gets to take a bath daily.<n>* It should not be left alone.<n>* It should be carried in a carrier box when travelling and not left in the car because it can get suffocated.<n>* It should never walk to the bathroom on it own because it may fall in the tub or the toilet and drown.<n>* It is not advisable to leave it in an empty

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A. Opens<n><n>B. Closed<n><n>C. At shower<n><n>D. Falling down<n><n>E. The correct answer is D.<n><n>### Input<n>What's the difference between 3-/6 x 7 and (3-6)/6/7?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer:<n>```math<n>{3 - 6}*{7} - 3 - 6 - (3 - 6)*6/7<n>```<n><n>```<n>(1) - 3 - 9/7<n>```<n>```<n>= 5/7 -9/7 = 2<n>```<n><n>### Instructions<n>The following expression is made up of two parts. The first part is 10% of 40. You have to use the second part to calculate the first part, and then replace the first part in the expression. Complete the calculation.<n><n>```math<n>.10*40<n>```<n><n>```math<n>4/[(4/10)]<n>```<n><n>20<n><n>```math<n>20/(4/10)<n>```<n><n>4<n><n>```math<n>0.20<n>```<n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>The teakettle was made in England and kept in the cupboard.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Cupboard: cupboard<n><n>Countertop: countertop<n><n>Water: water<n><n>Hardware department: hardware department<n><n>England: england<n><n>#### <n>Answer: A<n>## Task<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the chart by writing the value below the x-axis and the fraction below the y-axis under the appropriate headings.<n><n>```<n>    y-axis   1<n><n>    x-axis | Value Headings<n><n>       __    __<n>       -     -<n>     +    -    -<n>      /       \ <n>    (15)     _____<n>      \      /<n>        (300)<n><n>    y-axis| 6/10<n><n>    x-chart|<n><n><n><n>Input : (15/6) x (300/15) =?<n><n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? Choices:  A: cause spots on leaf B: healthy C: wellness D: ball stopped E: cure<n><n>### Response:		Healthy<n>### Rationales:The cause of the disease is well known.<n>The researchers don't need a cause if they're trying to cure the disease.<n>They also don't need a cure if they know the cause.<n>They're seeking a wellness, which is a way to stop the spread of the disease.<n>They're also seeking ways to prevent it altogether.

Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		The right words are B and C<n><n>### Dem:<n>Input: There are 6842 houses in a city. The last digit is 2, and the second digit must be odd. There are 6 houses ending with 2. Everyone in the town has an odd numbered house. The first digit is 2,789 or greater. What is the first digit?<n><n>Rationales: Each group of numbers 2,78,9,6 is 4.<n>So, the first number must be 4,521,0,3,0.<n>The number ends with 0, meaning it is 1 less than the one before it, so the fifth number has an odd ending. (Odd x Odd = Even)<n><n>The last digit is 2.<n>That means it has to be one of 3,5,7,9, which is the second digit.<n>The only one of those with a 2 in it is 521.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: shelf B: cellar C: refrigerator D: cupboard E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		Answer: D<n><n>### Input:(1) (A): I like to play football.<n>(B): (A) Me too.<n>(C): (A) Too.<n>(D): (B) I never play.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If the receiver agrees, they respond with a phrase that shows concurrence such as (A) Me too, (B) Too, or (D) I never play. If they disagree, they respond with a question or a phrase that indicates not doing something such as (B) I never, (C) I don't either, or (E) Neither do I.<n><n>(1A):I like to play football. (1B): Me too. (1C): I agree. (1D): I don't either. (1E): Neither do I. (2A): I like to go to the ball park. (2B): Neither do I.(2C): What's baseball? (2D): I'm not very good at baseball. (2E): Me neither, I don't like it very much. (2F): Not me.<n><n>### Input:-17 + 47<n><n>### Answer: -30<n><n>### Rationale:-17 + 7 = <<-17+7=24>>24.<n>-24 = <<-24=...>>.<n>-47 - 17 = <<-47-17=...>>.<n><n>The negative of 24 is -24

Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is: A: envious<n><n>If the teams are evenly matched, they both have an equal chance of winning and losing. Therefore, the spectators of a game that is evenly matched would want to find out if their team wins. They would not care if another team wins.<n><n>#### C<n><n>

It's also a place to eat, sleep, relax and wash clothes.<br/><n>B: pantry usually houses between 30 to 39 people and there is enough room left over from everyone to sleep.<n><br/><n>C: table usually houses 40-39 people and there's enough floor space between the dishes to sit and eat dinner.<br/><n>D: living room usually houses less than 30 people (more than 15) but there isn't enough floor space for them.<br/><n>E: shelf usually houses 15 – 10 people, there isn't enough room in the house for them.<br/><br/><n>D<n><n>### Input for the below multiple choice question.<n>The following problem has multiple solutions. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationale: The word "control" in the prompt "guide, understand, control, care, and vent" is in the most frequent position.<n><n>### Input<n>The school building has 24 classrooms and 3 science labs. In addition, there are 3 art rooms and 2 reading rooms. There are 2 teachers, 3 aides, and 6 special-ed teachers in the school. How many people can use each room 2, 3, or 4 times a week?<n><n>### Response<n>2, 3, 4<n><n>### Rationales: First, count the number of rooms with one use: 24 rooms × 2= <<24x2=48>>48.<n>Now, count the number of uses for each room: (24+3+2)= <<24+3+4=30>>30. (30 rooms x 2)= <<30x2=60>>60.<n>Thus (24+3) × 2 = <<48+60>>108, which must be evenly divided by 3 teachers, 4 rooms x 2 teachers, 2, 4, 6 aides, and 4 rooms for 3 special education teachers.<n>48+60 = <<48+310>>368, which is evenly divisible by 3 with rest = <<368-3=365>>365.<n>Therefore, the number of times is 37 = <<37*4=148>>148. Therefore,<n>  37 of them go 2 times   (148\*2=<<148x2=296>>296)<n>  37 of those go 3(times 35 = <<35*2=70>>70)<n>   37 of those are going 4 times (70\*4= <<70*4=280>>280)<n><n>### Answer: 296<n><n>### Input :<n>The restaurant manager gave a ticket for 75 cents and the cops gave a ticket for 150 cents. How much do they give a ticket? <n><n>### Response :

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a fishing rod? Choices:  A: furniture store B: fishing camp C: hardware store D: sporting goods store E: engine<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### D<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Furniture store sells a house but fishing is not a room (B) in a house.<n>Fishing camp is located near a lake, but a fishing rod can be bought in a hardware or a sporting goods store.<n>An engine is not a type of equipment to catch a fish.<n><n>### 51<n>Answer: A<n><n>Input: A new study by the American Heart Association shows that exercising every day for just 30 minutes or more reduces the risk of dying by cardiovascular disease by about one third, compared with doing only one session of at least 20 minutes. Why was the study important to do?<n>Rationales<n>The study showed that exercising 30 minutes or longer reduces the risk of dying from cardiovascular problems by about one-third.<n>The study showed the importance of staying fit because it showed that exercise is essential to improve health.<n>Risk of dying from cardiocervivoural problems is reduced by about one-third when individuals exercise 30 or more minutes on regular, consistent basis.<n>#### 32<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input：Which is more accurate? Choices: A: One of the best ways to study is to read your textbook over and over. B: One of the best way to study is to read over the textbook after studying the lesson.<n><n>### Response：<n>#### B<n><n>### Rationale<n>If one of your best way to study is A, then you will read the text over and over and after that, you will study to the lesson to the best of your efforts.<n>If one of your way of study is B, you will just read the text over and after you have studied the lesson.<n>#### 34<n>Answer: B<n>***

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If I take my heifer out East, where's a place we might end up? Choices:  A: new hampshire B: dairy farm C: farm field D: texas E: county fair<n><n>### Response:		Choices:<n>  I would take my heifer home, but I've been getting a lot of "offers" from wealthy farmers saying that they would have a place for her for a very generous sum of money. I've been thinking about it a lot because I believe that they are trying to bribe me to give up my prized heifer. What do I do? <n><n>  My prized heifer is my best friend and she has been the best animal that I have ever had. She has the best qualities and is the strongest one of the bunch, but when the time comes for me to take her home, there is something wrong. She looks sad and I can feel her anxiety, even though I am not going anywhere. Why is she stressed out? <n><n>  They say that the heifer is better off where she is at. He says that she will be safer there and that they will pay more to own her, so there is no sense in me taking her any more. I guess that it doesn't matter to me where she goes, as long as she is happy and safe. She is my best friend and I want her to be taken care of.<n><n>#### 20<n><n>Answer: I do not know, sir.<n><n>### Output: A: "Thanks, but no thanks. I've got everything that I need right now. I also don't like the idea of taking my prized heifer out east to a dairy farm. You'll need an extra cow out there to provide milk and I don't wanna have to carry an extra cow around anywhere. If the cow does give a lot of milk, don't eat it all. If you get hungry or thirsty, come over to my house for a meal and some drinks. How far will he travel in the summer when the temperature is 10 degrees warmer?<n>Rationales:- (summer temperature) = 10 - (winter temperature) = <<10-(-20)=30>>30 °F<n>- (300 feet in the winter) = <<300/x=40>>40 feet in the warm weather.<n>The distance in the summer will be (40) × (summer temp) = <<40*30=1200>>1200 feet<n>#### 1200<n>Answer: 1200

Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n><n>### Response:		<n>In an auditorium, the audience is typically the loudest at a [theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theatre) which has a stage on which people typically perform plays or musicals.<n>[Theatrical performers](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/theatrical_performer) include actors, dancers, and musicians.<n>These audiences in a theatre shout, sing, and clap to show their appreciation or enjoyment of the performance. <n><n><n>Hockey games are [arena-based](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Arena&action=edit&diff=prev&oldid=681489488) and usually have several [spectators](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/spectator). <n>They shout and wave their arms during games to show the players support and/or demonstrate their displeasure with a referee or the opposing team.<n><n>Movie theater audiences can be rowdy or calm, depending on the genre of movie. <n>Typically, audiences in a movie theater sit quietly and listen to the dialogue spoken by the characters on the big screen.<n><n>People attending [festivals](https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Festival_(events)) and [events](https://en.xn—-8sdbb28h80a.com/search-results/?s=event) are usually boisterous and lively due to the nature of the events such as music festivals, parties, and concerts.<n><n>#### A: show<n>B: theatre<n>C: hockey game<n>D: movies<n>E: event<n>Answer:<n>The audience is the loudest at [theatre](https:/en.wikipedia.org.wiki/Theatre)<n><n>### Input : Janet spent 1 31/12 of her weekly allowance at the movie theater. Example: If you answer: They took a break from all<n>the rides to have luch. Then the answer should be:  They took a break from<n>all the rides to have lu**c**h (Correct spelling).<n><n>#### B:<n>You can also ask for clarification of the question to be sure you have understood the task before you write a response.<n>Example: If you answer: Then write back with: "I'm confused. I'm supposed to write an<n>appropriate response to the question, but the question says they took<n>a break...."<n><n>---<n><n>### Input :<n><n>### A: They took a break to have lunch.<n><n>### B: They took a break while they had lunch.<n><n>You must choose either A OR B.<n><n>### You need to read the instructions in the beginning of the activity. I wrote them at the bottom,  and I<n>provided instructions about how to write a response  also at the bottom.<n><n>* You must use commas, periods and end each sentence in lower case.<n><n>### There is no need to capitalize the first word in the sentence: They took a break and had lunch.<n>OR: They took a break, and had lunch. <n><n>* There is no need to start the sentence with a capital letter: They took a break<n><n>### Make sure to end in a lower case letter:  They took a<n>break to have lunch. <n>AND NOT:  They Took a Break To Have Lunch.<n><n>------<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### A.<n>Choices:  A:heartburn <n>B:have fun C:enjoy <n>D:gas E:food poisoning<n><n>## Rationales 1:<n><n>### D has an extra "c" at the end of food<n><n>### In the first answer heartburn and gas do not rhyme and do not start with an "h"<n><n>### Rationels 2: <n><n>## B.  Enjoy, hamburger do not rhyme.<n><n>## C

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Sarah took poison by accident She found it in the cabinet and. thought that it was what? Choices:  A: drinkable B: junk food C: medicine D: antidote E: nutrient<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is A<n><n>### Incorrect answers:<n><n>###### B<n>Sarah took the junk food and later she found out that it was poisonous and not drinkable.<n><n>###### C<n>Medicine is what is given to a patient as medicine.<n><n>###### D<n>Antidotes are used on someone with the poison in him.<n><n>###### E<n>Nutrients are what are found in some food.<n><n>### Sources:<n><n><<CLEP, College Composition Skills Level 1 Manual>>, 2006.<n><n><<Institutional Learning Outcomes/College-Level Examination Program>>, 2012.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where would there be a connection to go to another place? Choices:  A: wires B: electrical circuit C: computer network D: wall E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		A: wires<n><n>### Input and Rationale: Janine spent 5 hours of her vacation reading. She also spent 2 hours cleaning and 3 hours playing. After her cleaning and playing, she had enough time to complete the last task on her list. For how long did she spend on her last task if she spent 3 hours on that activity during the rest of her vacation?<n>Rationales:(A) Janine started at 12 pm with reading. There were 4 hours left of her vacation after her reading. She then spent 2 more hours on cleaning.<n>(B) Janine spent 2 more hours cleaning and had 4 hours left of the day. She then spent 3 hours playing and had 2 hours left to complete her task.<n>(C) Janine started with writing in 3 pm at noon. She then started using her computer at 8 pm. There were 2 hours left of her vacations when she started. She wrote for 7 hours and 30 minutes, so there were only 30 minutes left of her vacations to complete her task, so she would not finish her task.<n><n>### Janine spent: 9 hours and 30 mins on task, 7 hours and 45 mins playing, 4 hours on vacation and 2 hours cleaning.<n>(D) Janine started at noon when vacations started. She had 4 hours left after the cleaning and playing. Then she spent 2 hours on a task.<n>(E) Janine did not complete another task.<n><n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7.<n><n>Input: A man has a number in mind that is divisible by 8. That man decides to add an 8 to the number. He adds 128 to the number and adds on an 8 again. Is the man satisfied that he has an even number now? How did the man decide if the number was even or odd? Explain your answer.<n>Rationales: Even numbers can be made with a one two or four by doubling it.<n>E: 128 + 128 +8 = <<128+128+8=334>><n><n>In this case, the number is an even number.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What white meat goes well with potatos? Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: maryland C: chicken D: tuna E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		D<n>#### D<n>Answer:  D<n><n>### Input :The number is 6. It is divisible by 2. It has 1 fewer than 12.<n><n>What is it? Choices: 1 A: 3 B: 2 C: 4 D: 4 E: 5 F: 4<n><n>### Response  : F<n>#### F<n>Answer:  F<n><n>### Input   : What is your name? Choice: A: Jane, a name B: a name Jane C: Jane, a name Jane D: Jane is E: my name is<n><n>### Response : Answer: D<n>#### D	<n>Answer:  D	<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:His running escape didn't last long once he tripped, perhaps he should've thought to what? Choices:  A: tie shoelace B: rest C: tiredness D: run longer E: sit down<n><n>### Response:		Choice (a) <n><n>Input:How many blocks, not counting the garage, did Pete travel in one direction before he got back to his house?<n>Rationales:Blocks traveled in each direction are 8 + 20/2 = <<8+20/2=10>>10 blocks.<n>There were 10 blocks traveled in one direction.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What creatures performing pollination are loved my millions? Choices:  A: birds B: action C: butterflies D: happiness E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		_____________<n>Rationales: <n><n>#### Answer: C<n><n>### Input:(Write your answer) What is not a factor of twelve? Choices: 1: 10, 11, 12 2: 4, 6, 8 3: 2, 3, 4, 6<n><n>### Demostration: (Write your answer) Write a response by selecting a choice from the above choices.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. 10, 2x10, 12...<n>2. 2x4, 3x8...<n>3. 2x2, 3x3...<n>Even if all are factors<n>### Answer: 2<n><n>### Input :<n>In a store, you will see the following prices: 898989.66,444444.81,232323,222222.30. The total of these prices may be represented by the _______.<n><n>### Answer: $3 (18 digits)<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store dirt in my home, where could I put it? Choices:  A: fingernails B: garden C: corner D: computer E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Choice A: fingernail<n>- Choice B: A:garden<n>- Choice C: corner<n>- Choice D: computer<n>- Choice E: closet<n>- Choice Answer: A: fingerniles<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input : My friend, Mark, works for a company that hires people. How many employees does his company have? Choice : More than 3,000 B: At least 200 C: More than 500 D: At least 24 E: Less than 300 <n><n>### Response Choices : A: 	 At least 20 E: 260<n><n>### Answer Choice : More than ___ B: 	 More than 3, 000 D answer Choice: C: 	 A minimum of 24

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What do you fill with ink to print? Choices:  A: squid B: pencil C: newspaper D: fountain pen E: printer<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>Input: What do you fill with in a newspaper? Choices: A: ink B: crayon C: paint D: pencil<n><n>### Response A<n><n>Input: You can play 90 pieces to win at _______________. Choices: A: checkers B: chess<n><n>### Response B<n><n>Input: If a book costs 23.5 dollars and you can buy 1.75 books, how much money do you have left?<n>Rationales<n>The number of books that you can buy is 23.5/1.75 = <<23.5/0.75=30.7>>30.7<n>If you have more money than the number of books you can buy, there is leftover money that you haven't spent.<n>Therefore, if your money minus 30.7= money -(30.7)=money is greater than or equal to 0, there is some money left or leftover.<n>The sum is 0 because you spend your money, but for this question you have some money left over or leftover since you have more money than what you can buy in the bookstore.<n><n>### Answer: 0<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>What do you call the lines that show a plan? This is called a<n><n><n>### Dem:<n>Input: Jan lost one quarter while shopping. He spent 85 cents for food. That night he lost a quarter more. How much did he lose altogether?<n>Rationales Answer: The number of quarters lost altogether is 85 +((0.25*2)+0.25) = 85 + (0.5 + 0.25)<n>Since Jan lost a quarter in the grocery store, there is 1 more quarter lost, and there is another quarter lost 2 more times, (or 3 times) totaling to 1 + 2 +3=6.<n><n>### A: 6<n>Answer: 6 quarters<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:I wanted  a side chair for people to visit me while I worked, where did I have it put? Choices:  A: building B: office C: library D: table E: bathtub<n><n>### Response:		<n>I bought a chair to place next to a building.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer:<n>### Input:Write a multiplication equation for 24 × 39.<n><n>### Response:"24" is the known and "39" is the unknown.<n><n>24 is times or multiplyd by 39.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 886<n><n>### Input"<n>"Multiply \(434\) × \(19\).<n><n>### Response<n><n>"434" is the known or given number and "19" is the unknown or question number.<n><n>434 is times or multiply by 19.<n><n>#### 8936<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n><n>**Write a multiplication equation to represent multiplying the following numbers** :<n><n>### Instructors Response:<n><n>The correct answer is 568.<n><n>__568__<n><n>__The answer is 561_.<n><n><n>### Instrument of the following exercise:<n><n>### Responsibility:<n><n>**Write an array to represent the following number** <n><n>**Write the equation to represent the following number.**<n><n>\section{Input:I wanted a chair by the table so I had to multiply 8 by the number of times the number of times I needed for the table to do**<n><n><n>\section{Answer:8}<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is the biggest speech in the capital? Choices:  A: each state B: gettysburg address C: state of union D: each country E: europe<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: gettysburg Address<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Gettysburg Address is in the capital
