How many ingredients are there in his breakfast?<n>Rationales The ingredients are bread, ketchup, butter, chicken, and sauce since ketchup and butter are ingredients of sauce which is on top of the bread.<n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: You have $${{x_1}}$${\$\displaystyle x_1$$} pieces of $${{b_1}}$${\"\$$b_1\$}\$ and $${{y_1}}$${\$y_1\$}{\$y_1}$$ pieces of $${{b_{1:}}$}$${\$b_{1:}$$}{\"\$b_{1:}\$}$$ and you have $${{x_2}}$${\$x_2\$}$$x_2$$ pieces of $${{c_1}}$${\$$c_1\$}{\"\$c_1\$}$$ where $${{x_1+x_2}}$$ {\$\displaystyle x_1+x_ 2$$}$x_1$ is $${{y_1+x_1}}$$ {\$\displaystyle y_1+x_  1$$}$y_1$$ and $${{y_2}}$${\"\$$y_2$$}$y_2$$ is $${{b_{1:}+x_1}}${$b_{1:}+x_1$$}$b_{1:}$$. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		Exercise involves moving around. This is why it releases a lot of energy. Choice B is the best answer.<n><n>### Rationale:Thinking about a problem, trying to understand it, and working these problems out in your head involves exerting your brain cells. This uses up a lot of energy. However, choosing the right answer needs to be done for you to succeed in exercises, and this can’t be done without energy.<n><n>## Exercise:In this exercise, write a response that appropriately answers questions posed to you in this chapter. Your responses should reflect careful thinking. <n><n>Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>What would release energy, BUT not mainly in your muscle? <n><n>	<n>> Choices:  A) vent B) think C) shouting D) work-off E) exercise Answer: 2) <n><n>### Exercise:What is a major factor in making the decision to exercise? Choices: A) the weather B) time C) money D) convenience Answer: 3) <n><n>How much energy does exercise burn off? A) almost none B) enough to keep the body healthy C) 1400-1600 calories D) too much to burn off Answer: 4) <n><n>**Exercise: **Which statement about exercise is most true? Choices: <n>	<n>1.  The body is an efficient, well-oiled work machine.<n>	<n>2.  Exercising takes a lot of energy out of the body.<n><n>Answer: 2) 2) <n>> Choices: Exercising takes more energy out of the body than the average human uses during a day. <n><n>You're ready to move on. <n><n><n>> [](https://github.com/johnnyheller589/Exercise#-89.5)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:He had a hard time finding the room on his schedule, it was on the second floor and he got lost in the very large what? Choices:  A: accomplish B: learn about C: money D: notoriety E: religion<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option D<n><n>### Input, Rationales, Answer, Solution Comments:<n><n>Input: How is the following diagram drawn?<n><n>### Solution Comments<n><IMAGE><n>Rationales:<n><img src="/images/2020/7/12/20200712134016.png" width="100%" alt="20200615131832"></img><n><n>### Input<n>The above figure depicts the following system which is best described as: a) a system without feedback; c) a single loop system in which a set point is defined; b) a stable system b. which can oscillate around its set point due to feedback; d) a system which has the potential to exhibit a limit cycle, but never does so.<n><n>### Answer<n>a.<n><n>### Comments<n>Brief Comment:<n><img src="https://i.imgur.com/Eh7u3zZ.jpeg" width="1024" alt="img"/></img><n>Rationales:[b] The above figure depicts a feedback-controlled system (i.e., a system that has feedback ). Systems with feedback can have a stable set point about which the system oscillates (the above example, b), can have a stable set-point but oscillate beyond this point (the above example, c), or can have a stable set -point but not have a stable equilibrium as the result of a period in which the set-point moves up or down (the above example, d). None of the above figure’s options describes a system that has potential to exhibit a stable equilibrium but never does so, which is the answer choice represented in A.<n><n>### Input 2, Solution Comments<n><n><n><n>### Input and Comments<n>#### Input1<n>The process shown below has the given rate  reactants and is producing.<n><n>### Answer Choices:  A. 5 units of Y per second B. 7 units per second of Y C. 3 units per second of Y D.  -3 units per second of X E. 0 units per second of Y<n><n><n><n>## solution and comments<n>### Input 1<n>#### Input:The process shown below has th rate \[ \[2\] react

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a shopping bag for packing groceries? Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: supermarket<n>- B: home<n>- C: closet<n>- D: mart<n>- E: hardware store<n>---<n><n>### How would you respond to each question?<n>- Write 2.<n>- Write the number 5.<n>- Write the value 1<n>- Write the value ___________.<n>- Write the value `40/2`.<n><n>### How many ways can you get from the starting point to the finish point in each problem?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:How does a flea locomote? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a bookstore? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If you aren't experiencing curiosity and want to ensure viewing enjoyment, what may you watch? Choices:  A: examine thing B: stare into a mirror C: go somewhere D: hear news E: see favorite show<n><n>### Response:		B is the correct response.<n><n>### Rationales:A: examine thing; B: stare into mirror; C: go somewhere; D: hear news; E: see favorite show:B is the correct answer. To go somewhere you must stare into a mirror and hear news.<n>To get to somewhere, you must examine thing and see favorite show.<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### InputThe city of Detroit is the largest city in the state of Michigan. How many times is larger than the city of Chicago, Illinois?<n>##### Rationales<n>The city of Detroit is 2 times larger than the city of Detroit.<n><n>The city of Detroit has 3 places larger than the city of Illinois Chicago.<n><n>Chicago has 3 points. the size of the city of ill-inois <n><n>The city of Chicago has 1.5 times the size of the city <n><n>Therefore the city of ill-Chicago has 3 times the size.<n>The city of Detroit Chicago is 3 times more than its size.<n><n>#### 1.5 times more<n>The city of Chicago  is 1.5 times larger than you.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n><n>### Response:		C: dirty.<n><n>### Rationales:Corrupt is a synonym of contaminate.<n>Dead is a synonym of pure.<n>Applied is a synonym of fresh.<n>A purification process is a type of fresh sample.<n>Therefore, the lab assistant got the sample dirty.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:A large container was a dime a dozen, there were hundreds of rows of them in the giant what? Choices:  A: factory B: garden C: supermarket D: garage E: warehouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>#### Rationales<n>The large container was a dodecahedron, which is 12-sided. For the container to have a dime a dozen meant that it was a hodgepodge or scattered collection of many dimes, or 10 cents. In the case of this container, it was one large container with many rows of large containers inside. Therefore, the choice is E: warehouse.<n><n>#### Input:A pizzeria in Texas ordered a large pepperoni pizza, a medium sausage pizza, five small Hawaiian pizzas, and ten large pizzas for a big party. How many pizzas were ordered in all? Choices: 108 B: 118 C: 101 D: 9 E: 107<n><n>### Response<n>E<n>#### E: 101<n>Answer: Ten small pizzas were ordered with the large and  the medium pizzas, totalling to 20, and with the 101 large and  medium pizzas ordered, 5 and 50 were the only ways in which these could add up to 101.<n><n>#### Rationaleses<n>The answer is E: 109. Ten were ordered for the party to make 110 total. This was one more than ten, for a total of 11, hence 110. When a person orders an item, it is a fraction and the order is divided into  how many parts. Thus, adding another pizza to the total  makes ten extra pizzas, for a grand total of 110 (100 + 10)<n><n>### Input Answers:<n>#### Answer: 12<n>Input: An iceberg is often called a hundredweight. Which of the following best describes the definition of a hundredweight? A: Something in metric units B: Something in imperial units C: Something in weight in kilograms D: Something that is not a unit<n>Rationales: While icebergs may be called hundredweights, the definition of a hundred weight is most definitely not a metric unit. In metric units, a hundred weight is equal to 100 kg, while an iceberg would need to be at least triple that to be properly called a hundred

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where might a yard be tiny? Choices:  A: farmland B: neighborhood C: city D: property E: subdivision<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Rationales: An in- town yard is always bigger than<n>than a yard in the countryside.<n><n>### Response Summary<n><n>---<n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If they were celebrating the occasion, how could the occasion be described? Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		They were celebrating in A and B<n><n>### Output:The word "drinking" is correct.<n><n>Input:  When was the last time you drank chocolate milk?<n>Rationales:(This is the correct response) It has been months since I last drank chocolate<n><n>### Output - Explanation<n><n>#### The answer<n><n>This sentence sounds like the question asked was "When was the last time that you drank choc<n>late milk?"<n><n>The correct response is<n>the 2nd choice: "It has been months since I drank chocolate."<n><n>### Input - Explanation<n>#### The mistake<n><n>The input sounds like the question asked is "When was the last _______________ you dr<n>inked chocolate milk?"<n><n>#### What you didn't do<n><n>You missed that "last" is an adverb that should be followed with a past participle or pas<n>t form (adjectival) and not an article "a" or "an".<n><n>So the sentence should have something like the following grammatical structure:<n>(Last ______________), and you ate chocolate milk.<n><n>### Output<n><n>The correct response to the question is the 2nd choice: "[When was the last t<n>ime] that you drank choco<n>late milk?" And the answer to that would be "It has been months...'<n><n>### Question<n><n>The correct response that the system returned is correct.<n><n>#### What happened?<n><n>**Question:** How could you be described at the end of the day? Choices: A: tiredness B: happiness C: frustration D: weariness E: restfulness<n><n>#### The right answer<n><n>"D" answers this question correctly, because tiredness can be described as a state of sleepiness or weariness.<n><n>### Input<n><n>We made a lot of sales today. What was your total for the day?<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>The person was asking how much money the person made for a day. You are calculating sales<n>based on the total sale price and the number it took to sell one item. We assume that the<n>person is only paid per item sold and not for all sales regardless of how many items are<n>sold in one day.<n><n>### Example<n>Let's say

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:John's RV needs electricity so that he can cook lunch. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input：Sophia’s father has traveled to more U.S. states and Canadian provinces than any other person on earth, except her grandmother. Her grandmother had also traveled to every U.S. state, but she has gone farther north to visit every Canadian province. Sophia’s father has three American states left to visit and has never been to Bermuda while her grandmother has been there. What states are left to visit so that neither person can complete their goal of going to each U.S. state and Canadian province?<n><n>### Demand:<n>The state is not specified. Sophia's grandmother should be able to visit Alaska, because her father is not there.<n><n>### Rationalization:<n>The states that should not be visited are South Dakota, Idaho and New Hampshire, because all are already visited by Sophia's grandfather. We know New Hampshire is the remaining state because it has been visited by her father. Therefore, the states that should not be missed are Alaska (because New Hampshire has already been visited by the two).<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Bermuda, Alaska<n><n>***<n>### Instruction：Answer the multiple choice questions based on the information and figures presented in the paragraph below.<n><n>### Explanation：<n><n>### Instructions：<n>Input: Which shape has more sides? Choices: A: 2 B: 3 C: 4 D: 5 E: 6<n><n>### Response：<n>### A<n><n>### Demorstration：<n><n>## Input:<n>A 9-sided figure has fewer sides than a figure that is 8-sided or has more sides.<n>In the 1st scenario where the figure can be 9-sided, there are 9/8 <98=11.25 ways to create a 9-sided triangle, and 8/7 <87=1.14% to create a 8-sided figure.<n>Therefore, "9 has more sides than 5 and 6".<n><n>### Answer：<n>In the left figure, 9-sided triangles are 11.25% than 8-sided.<n>In the right figure, 9-

The difference between one of them and 3 is 3. What are the numbers?<n><n>### Rationales: 1 + 3 + 5 = <<1+3+5=9>>9<n><n>5 + 7 + 9 = <<5+7+9=19>>19<n><n>8 + 11 + 13 = <<8+11+13=32>>32<n><n>89 - 3 = <<89-3=86>>86<n>86 + 9 = <<86+9=95>>95<n>9 + 5 = <<9+5=14>>14<n>#### 14<n>Answer: 14<n>#### <n>## Parting Advice<n><n>As the course unfolds, you’ll notice that your instructor gives more specific instructions and rationales as the task becomes more complex. To help you organize your thinking before responding to a task, I’ve created this graphic. Notice that the prompting question for the task is in the center of the graphic, and the questions for your response can be placed at each of the circles, depending on the complexity of the task.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is someone watching a person who is playing guitar doing? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:One way to relieve your hunger if you live near the coast is to do what? Choices:  A: grill B: go to market C: bring home fish D: eat hamburger E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is "Grill" because if you live near the ocean, you can grill.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n><n>You can grill in your BBQ and it is one of the way to relieve your pain.<n>You can also hunt seafood in the sea.<n>### The answer is Grill<n>### Answer: G<n><n>### Input:"Mara and Jason are on separate teams but have scored 6 points in all." Which of the following values must contain exactly one zero? Choice: A: 2-5 B: 3-9 C: 4-5 D:4-6 E: 6-9<n><n>### Response:"The answer is B"<n><n>### Rationles"<n><n>The possible zero number are 0-3,0-9,0-4 and0-6"<n>"there must be exactly one zero number in the choices"<n>"there must have no zero in number zero-4"<n>"there must no zero in zero-4" <n>Because<n>0-3=0-9 is not an exact zero,<n>zero-4 is also not an exact zero because 0-4 contain 0.<n>Because zero have a number 4 in it.<n>It means we should eliminate A,C,D and E<n><n><n>### The answer:B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The shelf was showing signs of instability, what should the carpenter fix to avoid any issues? Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		The  Carpenter should fix the wall since a weak wall may collapse at any point.<n><n>### Input Two 16-digit passkeys are the same if and only if they are exactly four letters apart in their decimal representation. For example, the passkeys<n>>>4174760095437558932<<41747-60095-43755-8932<n>and <n>>>4163700954975089321<<41637-00954-97508-9321<n>are the same. (Two words in English.) The passkeys are different otherwise, if and only if they differ by some multiple of two characters. Find all possible pairs of passkeys that are<n>>>417576009-594375516<<41757-600-9-59421<<417650-760-9-537-55-16<n>different because of this property.<n><n>### Response<n>Find all pairs of passkey numbers with a difference of 2 between passkey numbers.<n>The total passkey numbers are 264<n>The total numbers of pairs of passkeys with a difference of 4 is <n>16!/(16-2) *2!(2^2-2*(2^0)! / 0!)<n>The difference of two passkeys equals "2*3*5*7"<n>2*3*5= 15<n>7= 6,8,9<n>Thus the Total pairs of passkeys that differs with a difference of 5 is 15!/(15-5)*5!<n><n>The total pairs of passkeys differences with a difference of 3 is found using<n>2!/(2-3)*3!<n><n>A difference of 2 contains 0,2<n><n>Thus the Total passkeys Difference values is <n><n>### Input <n>Which of the following elements of a coordinate triple is independent of the others? Choose all that are correct.<n><n>* A<n>* B<n>* C<n>* D (All are independent)<n>* E (The only choice.)

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The small cabin was not available, so they were upgraded to what? The difference between two numbers is  the difference between the two numbers.<n>  2. In other words, the difference between two numbers is the sum that you get if, for a certain value of x, x is subtracted from both numbers.<n>3. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What would you put in a container? Choices:  A: food B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: closet garage E: port<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I chose B: cargo ship.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:At a state fair judging pigs requires careful what? Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: In order to determine winners in a pig-judging competition, there must be fair evaluating.<n><n>Rationales: All choices refer to the task of pig-judging except for evaluating.<n><n>#### Evaluating<n><n>Answer: Evaluating<n><n>### Input :The two lines parallel to the x-axis and the line y x = -3 have <n><n>### Response : Choices: A: one common parallel line to the x-axis.<n>B: two line segments parallel to the -x axis.<n>C: a single line parallel to the – x – axis.<n>D: a single line segment parallel to the – x-axis.<n><n>### Response<n>Input: The two lines parallel to the line \(y = -3\) have at most one line segment parallel to the line \(x = -3\).<n><n>Rationales for Answer: All choices are not correct.<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input  :The perimeter of a square and the side lengths of a rectangle are two?  Choices:  A : quadrilaterals B : polygons C : triangles E: parallelograms<n><n>### Response  :  Choices:  B: Polygons<n><n>### Response   <n>Input: A rectangle and square have two different side lengths.<n><n>Rational: In polygons, all four sides are the same.<n><n>#### B<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input ;A square is a rectangle with a? __ Choices:  A side of squares and rectangles has four angles of 90.<n><n>### Respose  :  Choices :  B sides Eight sides<n><n>### Response  <n>Input: A square has four angles of 60 degrees.<n><n>Eight sides of a square have 60°.<n><n>#### B <n><n>Answer: B <n><n>### Input;  Square and rectangle are different due to? Choices:  B sides having different angles<n><n>### Resposr : B<n><n>### Respostion<n>Input: The reason that a square and rectangle are different is that  a square has four sides that are congruent and have 90°, while a rectangle has sides that can differ.<n><n>#### B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The lady was doing a one man show of her tell story, when the show began she did what? She borrowed __<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input:#Sam went to school every weekday. She ate __<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Instructions: Choose the option that correctly identifies the quantity given.<n><n>### Rationales: The quantity is given by __.<n>### Demonstation:<n>7 × 9 = <<7*9=63>>63<n>7 × 9/2 = <<7*9/2=36>>36<n>63/2 = <<63/2=31>>31<n><n>### 31<n>Answer: 31<n><n>## Instructions: Solve the following application of the distributive property<n><n>## Demonstration: Expand the expression completely. Choices:  A: self pity B: communication C: understood D: pain E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is letter C.<n>- A: self pity does not apply because yelling does not express self pity.<n>- B: communication does not apply. The term self pity cannot be replaced by communication.<n>- D: pain applies because when you are yelling, you are feeling pain. However, it does not apply to the whole expression "self pity" and "yelling".<n>- E: embarrassment does not apply because you cannot feel embarrassment with yelling. Yelling is often associated with pain, so B is not the correct answer.<n>- C: understood is the correct answer because yelling cannot be replaced by understood.<n><n>### Input<n>- Rationales: When you are feeling self pity, what will you express? Choices:  a: by getting mad 😡 b: by yelling c: by talking d: by expressing yourself e: all are true<n>#### 😡 <n>Answer: <n><n>### Response<n>- The correct choice is "c", because when you feel self pity, you express yourself by yelling.<n><n>Input: When you are feeling happy after getting a report, what are you expressing yourself? Choices: 😊 😃<n><n>Answer: The correct answer is '😊'<n><n>- When you are feeling self-satisfaction what are you feeling? <n>- The correct answer is 😊<n>- The word '😃' represents 'Happy'<n><n>Input: When a student is expressing themselves, they are speaking to themselves, thinking silently, or sharing their ideas and beliefs to another person? Choices: 1st student is expressing themselves 2nd student is speaking to themselves 3rd student is thinking silently 4th student is sharing their ideas and belief to others<n><n>#### 1st student is speaking to themselves<n><n>Answer: The word given in the question is 'expressing themselves' in that context, 'expressing themselves' can be replaced by'speaking to themselves'.<n><n>Input: When the police arrest some criminal on the street, that is what they are doing. Choices: 1-being a thief 2-catching a thief 3-holding a thief 4-questioning a thief<n><n>#### 4-questionin a thief<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		Because this is a word problem, we need to read the question carefully and find out what information to solve the problem.<n>We read the question carefully. "In his apartment kitchen." We do not know what kind of kitchen it is, so we can't say where he would look for a potato or a pocket.<n>We also know that he is cooking a stew. We don't know if he is cooking the potato as a part of the stew, or not. That means that we don't know if what he is doing is using the potato or looking for a potato in the pantry.<n>This tells us that there is something confusing about the question, so we try to figure out the context to make sense of it.<n>If we read the question again it states "Where might he look for a Potato." This tells us that he is looking, not cooking.<n>Reading the question more carefully we realize that it describes two possible answers to the question:  (C) and (D).<n>The answer should be (C) because he is looking for a potato and not cooking with the potato.<n><n>####  B<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input : The teacher said it was Wednesday by giving a clue. This clue was " It is the day after Tuesday." Which day is it? Choices: Wednesday Thursday Saturday Sunday Monday<n><n>### Response :<n>Answer: Monday, because "it is day" and it is the day after day.<n><n>####  C<n>Answer: Wednesday<n><n><n><n><n><n>#### <n>Answer: Tuesday<n><n><n>####  D<n>Answer: Thursday<n><n><n>### Input  : I  walked 7 blocks   and 12 miles.  How many  blocks will I walk and how many miles will I  walk if I walk 1 block for 3 miles. Choices: 1: 24 blocks and 27 miles 2: 21 blocks and 19 miles  3. 19 blocks and  15.5 miles  4.  26 blocks and 20 miles 5.  30 blocks and 18 miles <n>The answer is 1: My first round was 12 miles. My second walk was 3 miles. My first walk was 12 - 3

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Therefore, Yes.<n>#### Yes<n>Answer:Yes<n><n>### Input:"Is it a rainy day?"<n><n>### Demostration:<n>#### No<n>Rationales:"Rain" means rain but not rain.<n>#### No<n>Answer:No<n><n>### Input"Is it a hot day?"<n><n>##demostration:<n><n>### Demos:<n>#### No<n><n>#### No<n><n><n>### Answer:None :<n>### Answer:E<n><n>### Input:'Is it a sunny day?'<n><n>### Demoscne:<n><n><n>#### No<n>Rataions:Rain does not mean sunny.<n><n># Part 2<n><n>### Input<n>Government expenditures are often expressed in a percentage of their expenditures by the previous year. The rate of growth in expenditures of a country is said to be positive or negative if that growth is above or below the previous year. What would be the rate of growth if a country's tax revenues were $2 million last year and $2.5 million this year, the expenditures were $4 million last year and $4.5 million this year?<n><n>### Answer<n>The answer is positive. Last year tax revenues were $ 2 million  and expenditures were 4 million<n>And this year tax revenues were 2.5million and expenditures 4.5 million:<n><n>$4.5 million ÷ 4 $<=> (4.5 $)/4=$1.125<n>Which is bigger?<n>Last year expenditures were  4, now this year are 5.<n>$ > $<=><n>4 > 5<n><n>Therefore, the growth rate is 1.125 -1 = 0.125<n><n>Positive growth.<n><n><n>### Insttruction:Complete the request. Rewrite using transpositions.<n><n>### Request :Answer the following sentence.<n><n>### Sentence:Following the example of their colleagues, they all
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: grocery store B: nightstand C: armpits D: own bathroom E: medicine chest<n><n>### Response:		Answer: D<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Hamlet says,"I have nothing but a poor body and my _______." <n>```<n><n>### Rationales/Response<n>**Response:** We must first understand the prompt. This is Hamlet talking. Therefore, we are looking for a possessive pronoun to fill in the blank. We have the following choices:<n><n>```<n>   a. his <n>   b. his own<n>   c. her/her own<n>   d. its<n>   e. its own<n>```<n><n>As the sentence progresses, we see that Hamlet's mother is speaking in regards to the "worm-eaten ______."<n><n>While we have seen that the worm-eaten body refers to Hamlet's body, that's not what Hamlet's mother means. She means that it's the worm-eated body that is asking for rest. So, to figure out what Hamlet's body is asking for, let's continue:<n><n>```<n>Hamlets words after: '_______' means my rest.<n>```<n><n>So now we know Hamlet's body (the worm-eaten one) is asking for rest. Based on the previous sentences, it should be assumed his wife and mother are giving him rest in their bedrooms if they have rooms where they can give him rest (i.e., Hamlet's bedroom). So, we end up with:<n><n>```<n>A: grocery store   <n>  b: nightstand<n><n>    C: Armpits   <n>  D: own bathroom<n><n>       E: Medicine Cabinet<n>```<n>So, let's look at the choices in sequence.<n>```<n>A: Grocery Store<n>                 <n>           Not the answer. No way.<n>```<n>We can't see how him asking his wife to pick him pink or yellow soap at the store will help him with his body odor, but we do see that it might help us get a better clue if there's more to this story than we can figure out at the moment. However, there is a more clear indicator for us to answer this question.<n><n>```<n>B: Nightstand<n><n>```<n>We see that his wife goes and gets him something to help him and then comes to him with the deodorant. This
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is C because when we are thankful for something we always smile.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Input<n>When we are thankful what do we do? <n><n>### Multiple Choices:<n>A. Say thank<n>B. Smile <n>C. Looking for D. get more <n>E. Show appreciation<n><n>## 5.3.1<n>In the previous question, think about writing the instruction by considering the following:<n>* The input must be the question for which the student must select the answer.<n>* The multiple choice question must describe the instruction clearly in a way that the student can understand what the correct answer is. <n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a new instruction that provides the answer choice that is given in the list. <n><n>## 5 Instructions<n>**Write instructions that direct the student to use a rational explanation to determine how much a particular item cost, if another item is a dollar more or less than the original item.**<n>Here are some sample questions that the student will answer. The student will select one of the answers they provided<n><n>Sample: Janine has a dress that is a dollar more than an umbrella, but she does not have the umbrella. If Janine wants the umbrella, how much does it cost?<n>Rationales<n>Example 1: If Janine's dress is \$1 more than the umbrella, her dress costs \$1 more than the answer choice \$1 = <<1=1>>1.<n>  <n>Example 2: If Janine'​s dress is \$1 less than the umbrella and the umbrella is $5 less than 6, then the umbrella must cost \$4 = <<1*4=4>>4. Therefore, the umbrella costs \$4 - <<<4-6=0>>0> - <<<4-1=3>>3 + <<<1-0=1>>1. In sum, the umbrella must be \$4 - <<<1=1>>1 + \$. Janine's dress costs \$<<<4-1= 3>>3 - <<<1= 1>>1 and is a \$1 more than the choice answer.\

Duneier..."<n>"In recent years social movements have increasingly used Facebook. With about twenty million activist accounts, Facebook now has more users than any other social media site in the United States, and it's likely that most activist organizations are using the site to some extent."<n>"social activism movements such as BLM (Black Lives Matter) are changing the game for modern activism."<n>"As one of few African American women who has achieved this level of influence, she now has the opportunity to help activate young African American girls. This mode of protest is often called direct action."<n>"The movement was created to focus the strength from the 1940s Social Change, Civil Rights, Social Action, and Movement Activism (Kristal, 1991). The protests also included an element of political participation through lobbying and other legislative activities."<n>"However, the majority of this protesting did not result in the desired change of the law. One of the most prominent examples of such a demonstration was the 'Million Man March' that gathered about 1 million protesters on the steps of the National Mall in Washington, D.C. in 1995."<n><n>The same reasoning can be applied for Answer E: "Change yourself."<n>As mentioned above, the survey mentioned that three-quarters of the Millennials (aged 18-34) would take a social or political action."

This would mean the next thing 769 ends in would be 3.<n>```python<n>print("769 is divisible by 3. <n>Since it's the next multiple of 3, the next digit that 769 would end in is 3:<n>" " + str(x//3)<n>```<n>Next, we can add `2` to the end, since it was the next one above 7. Next, multiply 3 by 2:<n>```python<n>3*2<n>```<n>```python<n>print(3*2)<n>print("So now " + str(x*3) +  would have to be the next digit at 360")<n>if 360 is divisible by 7:<n>    print("")<n>    print("If not, then no more multiples of 3 exist in " + str(x))<n>```<n><n>Next comes 4, but since `4` ends with a `0` and 769 doesn't end with a `0`, `4` can't work.<n>Last comes `9`, if

Because spiders can survive up to 2 days even without eating, you are required to always keep cleaning on every corner of your house. That way, you won't get a big headache if you find a spider on or near the bed, sofa or the shower in the morning.

However, a yard is a place inside a house where the family grows their plants and have activities around the yard including playing ball inside the yard. A yard therefore made up of the following:<n>. 1) A house.<n>. 2) Buildings around the house like walls, fence, and gates.<n>. 3) The plants and the items that are inside the house like clothes, toys, and food.<n>So, we can say that a yard is made up of a house and what is inside it and the streets, roads and walls near the house.<n>####<n>Answer: A

Choices:  A: arlington B: church property C: out back D: every town E: cemetery<n><n>### Response:		Graveyards are built out back behind the church house.<n><n>### Input : Janet has 9 balls more than brenda. Mara has double the number as Janet. How man balls do Janet and Mara have in all if Martha has 40 balls less than 156?<n><n>### Response : Janet has balls 156-40=<<156-4(00 or 1)>>1 balls.<n>Mara has balls 118/2 = <<1 (0) /2= 59>>59.<n>Brenda has balls 59-9=<<59-9=40>>40.<n>So Janet's balls are 1+59+40=<<1+59+8=65>>65(bals), and Mara's balls are 65+59=<<65 +59=124>>124.<n>#### 124<n>Answer: 124<n><n>### Input A man walked 2 kilometer's from bus garage to post office he came back. The mileage on the way home was 35 km. How many kilometer's did he walk in all.<n><n>### Response A man walk 35/2=<<35/2=17(17km)>>km. and 3/4=<<3/4=5km>>5km on way home. Total 17+5=<<17+5=22(22Kms)>>22.<n><n>### Output<n>Janet has 89 more balls than brenda. Marion has 40 balls and 21 more balls than Janet. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of hosting a crowd? Choices:  A: few people B: pay debts C: individual D: single person E: small group<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n><n>### Input : Which word is misspelled:  Choices:<n>(1) A<n><n>(2) B<n><n>(3) C<n><n>(4) D<n><n>(5) E<n><n>### Response : (5)<n><n>### Input  : There are 26 letters in the English alphabet. Choices:<n>(A)   A<n><n>(B)   B<n><n>(C)   C<n><n>(D)   D<n><n>(E)   E<n><n>### Answer : (A):<n><n>### Input   : An elephant is tall.<n>Choices:<n><n>(1) A: an elephant is taller.<n><n>(2)   B: tall elephant<n><n>(3)   C: an elephant<n><n><n>### Answer:   (1)<n><n>### Instructions:An elephant is tall and an elephant is big. Choices:<n><n>(A) The elephant is neither tall nor big.<n><n>(B) The elephant must be very tall and very big.<n><n>(C) The elephant may be very tall. It may be very big.<n><n>### Answer (C): The elephant may me very tall. It may me very big.<n><n><n>### Input    : What does the suffix (y) after a word stand for?<n>Choices:<n>(A):   A: part or place<n><n>(B):   B: more than one<n><n>(C):   (C): part or pieces of<n><n>### Answer  (C): The suffix (y) after part or piece of<n><n>### Input      : The cat is in the tree. When you have used one word as a part of speech, the word keeps the same form. In the sentences below the word that has been used as a part of speech in the first sentence, changes to a different part of speech in the second sentence.<n><n>Choices:<n>* <n>(1)  A: is<n><n>(2)  B: part of<n><n>(3)  C: used<n><n>(4)  D: is used<n><n>### Answer(D) : The word is used in sentences.<n><n>### Input     : If you have ten red marbles and trade one marble
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What could fighting inflation cause if it is not successful? Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n><n>### Response:		A; The cause of not fighting inflation would be to have problems and not noticeable problems. <n><n>### InputHow many times do we add 1 to a two digit number to get a new two digit number?<n>RationalesWe will first look at the first number, so we add 1 to it. If we then look at the new number, We add 1 once more.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input1. How many hundreds in 773?2. How many ones in 242?<n>RationalesSince 773 has three digits, it contains a hundreds, tens, and a ones. <n>The hundreds in 772 would be 7hundreds and 2 tens. The ones would be 7+2=<<7+2=9>>9.<n>Since 242 has two digits it does not have a hundred, only a tens and a ones. So the one in 242 would be 2ones. <n>#### 0 and 2<n>Answer: 0 and 2

How many items does Alli have?<n><n><n>### Rationale:To find out how many items have aaron we can just minus what Aaron has and Alli have.<n><n>### Aarons list is Alli/333-a=A<n><n>### Alli=A/333-A=a<n><n>### Therefore A = 2442<n><n>### a=1425<n><n>### Input Alli = A/333-2442 =a = 1425<n>A = 2443<n>```<n>1425 = A<n>2442 = A <n>```<n><n>### Input A = 39<n>A/20  = a/5 = 39/5 = 19<n><n>### a = 78<n><n>`Rationales : To find out how many items Alli have. We just substract how many items Aaron has.`<n><n>### The next word is misspelred. Choices: 1. pencil 2. stroll 3. book 4. electronic 5. notebook 6. deskmate<n><n>### Input2:What type of writing is involved with a news article? Choices: 2. pencil 3. stroll 4. book 5. electronic 6. notebook 7. deskmate<n>### Instruction 1:<n>Choose the correct answer for the blank in the sentence. Choices A,B,C,D,E,F,G.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Please use an answer of C for the sentence. Writing a book requires writing with a<n>pencil. An answer of A is incorrect because you don't need a stroll to write a<n>book. A book cannot walk by itself or travel on a journey around the room. For<n>type 2, you need a pencil since you cannot type the words into an electronic<n>device. There is no deskmate. Thus, an answer of D is incorrect.<n><n>### Example1:A news article is created with a writing ____________.<n><n>### Answer 1:<n>C is for type 2. The first type is an article about a topic on which you write.<n>B is an incorrect answer because you cannot use a stroll for a news article.<n>D is incorrect since you cannot use an electronic device to write a news article.<n>Since an article is not a kind of article, G is incorrect.<n><n>####

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to thank someone for saying I have done a good job, what would I do? Choices:  A: smile B: shake hands C: express gratitude D: say you're welcome E: appreciate compliment<n><n>### Response:		A: smile<n><n>> **Directions:** Answer the questions, providing a complete sentence to complete the request. For each question, refer to the graph below as a guide to the appropriate answer. <n><n>### Demarcation: <n>The graph indicates how many cars are registered and the percentage of cars that have air conditioning and have power locks and windows.<n><n>Input: If the average cost of a new vehicle is $30,000, how much more does a truck cost than a car?<n><n>Rationales: 0.49 × $30,025 = <<0.49*30,026=14773>>14773 × 1.25 = <<14773*1.25=18232>>18232 x 10 = <<18232*10=182300>>18230 (answer) = $30,391,600<n><n>Input: Suppose that 2/3 of the people in Atlanta are black. How many black people are there in Atlanta?<n><n>Rational: To begin, we will use 2.3/3. To divide this fraction, you will multiply it by 1. Therefor the equation will change from (2.3/3) to 3(2.3/3). The equation then can be simplified to (6/3) Multiplying 6 by 10 = 60, To solve for the black people, subtract the total population from the number of black people. Therefor the number of black people would be (60 - 76/3). To put this fraction in decimal format, I multiply each numerator and denominator by 3 and the answer is.426825 42.<n><n>Input: A truck is 15 times heavier than a bike. How much does the bike weight?<n>Rationales The equation 15x(70) =70x(15) will yield 1200kg and 200kg respectively.<n><n>Input: Two-thirds of the food trucks in Kansas were destroyed in a snowstorm last year. How many are still operational?<n><n>Rationals We will

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? Choices:  A: nearest house B: workplace C: surface of earth D: office block E: his feet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Option A:<n>The human looked down longingly at Earth as he floated in the orbiting space shuttle.<n><n>#### Option B:<n>The human looked longingly at the Earth as he sat in the space station.<n><n>#### Option C:<n>The human looked below as he relaxed comfortably in the space station. <n><n>#### Option D:<n>The human gazed longingly at Earth as he stood in the space station.   <n><n>#### Option E: <n>The human looked down with longing and gazed down to earth.   <n><n><n>**Note:** The human could look down on his surroundings and gaze at Earth. Choice D and E are not the right answer choices.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Sam left his muddy shoes in the entryway.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		Sam is probably home, because he left his muddy shoers on the entry way to his house.<n><n>### Rationale: His house and school are indoor areas, so Sam can't be in school, garden or office building. His home is also an indoor area, since he put his muddy shoes on his entry way. There aren't any outdoor stores, as far as I know.<n><n>### 25<n>Answer: E

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		A:relaxation<n><n>### Input:(1) Brenda walked 34 miles before dark and continued to walk 9 miles more before arriving home. How many miles did she walk in all? (2) The temperature fell 9°F in one night. Write a real number expression to describe the change in temperature. Choices: 1. \(-6°F\) 2. \(92°F-39°F\) 3.-0.1° F 4. \(99°F+9°F- 34°F\) 5. -92°F<n><n>### Response (1) How many miles Brenda walked in all:<n><n>$$\begin{align} \textrm{The distance Brenda walked from home}\text{ before dark}&&\text{is}\left(1\text{ mile} \right) + \left( \frac{1}{2} \text{ miles} \right)\\&\text{The distance Brenda continued to walk}&& \text{is 9 miles}\\ \\ \textrm{The number that she walked in}\\\textrm{all }\text{is 20 miles}\end{align} $$<n><n>### Response(2) The changes in temperature:<n><n>$$\textrm{The temperature fell}\ \ \ 9\text{°F in one night}\ \ \ \left(\textrm{one night}\right) \(\text{\qquad}-\qquad \qquad }\)<n><n>$$\begin{-9\textrm{\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad }} \ 34\text{°F} \textrm{\qquad\qquad} \text{\qquad\qquad\times \qquad\qquad \qquad\qquad}7\text{-}\text{ °F}\qquad=\textrm{-}7\text{-9}= -16\text{-}\text 9\text{\qquad\qquad = 6\text{-}16 = 0\text{-32= -32}^{\circ }\text{C}\end{align} }$$<n><n>#### $-32°C$<n><n>Answer (2) $-32°C<n><n>### Input<n>The difference between 6,530 and 6,682 is \(\frac{449}{5}^{2}=207\). Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: cinema hall B: mall C: department store D: closet E: shop<n><n>### Response:		The clothing was likely purchased in the ____ ____ because it was so expensive relative to other places.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>C is the correct option. Closet implies a small space such as a bedroom closet. It could not be the place where the designer clothes were purchased. Additionally, mall would not be a place where expensive clothes were purchased. Lastly, the mall is a collection of stores. The store option, B, is not the correct choice. The department store is a place where other people sell their items. The department store may sell expensive clothes, but that would not make sense for the designers.<n><n><n>Input: Find me a restaurant that serves pasta. over.<n><n>### What i Have Done<n><n>### I have made the following codes to answer this task<n><n>### My First solution:<n><n>/**Write the code that computes the length of the character string.*/<n> How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? Choices:  A: war B: aircraft carrier C: sky D: graveyard E: crash<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: war is the answer because the war will be over, they don't give planes a grave yard so where can you bury those planes?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? Choices:  A: water B: liquid C: foamy D: intoxicating E: harmful<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A B C D E<n># Answer: Choices:  B C D E<n>B (water)<n><n>### Input<n><n>I have found how to print the value that is sent. However, since I use the parameter $var as my input, I can't pass it as a parameter when I need $var to assign the input I want to the function. Can anyone tell me how to pass the inputs?<n><n>### Answer:

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:When you experience boredom, what can you do on television? Choices:  A: watch film B: play cards C: play chess D: read news papers E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think watching film is the best thing to do to experience something new and to explore what the world has.

[answer: B,C].<n><n>### Next Instruction:Answer the statement below by drawing a circle around the correct value.<n><n>### Statement: 30 < (1 /3)^2<n><n>### Rationales: 30 < 1/3 * (1/3)<(1/3)^2.<n><n>30 is < 1/3.<n><n>1/3 is less that 30.<n><n>(1/3) is less that (1/3)^2 (3's second power).<n><n>### Squaring<n><n>### (a number)^2 = (1) * (number)^1 = (number)^(2)<n><n>### Example: 92=9 * 10, 9 * 10, or 9 to the power 2<n><n>### 3^2 = (3) * (3)<n><n>### Conclusions:<n>A square of any number is the square of the number.<n><n>### Next Rationales:Draw a circle around the number whose name you use in correct order.<n><n>### ( ) 15 12<n><n>### Circle around: 60<n><n>### Rationale 60 is the sum of the 15 and 12.<n><n># 2
