If Jan doubles her apples and Fred multiplies his apples by 2, Jan has 6 more apples. How many apples do Fred and Jan have altogether?<n>Rationales The sum of the number of apples in Jan and Fred are 17+6= <<17+6=23>>23 apples.<n>However, the number of the apples in Jan and the apples in Fred are <<17+6-7-4=12>>12.<n>Therefore, the sum of the number of the apple in Jan and Fred are \begin{code}<n><<12+12=24>>24 apples.<n>#### 24<n>Answer: 24<n><n>### Input<n><n>Answer - Input: The students took a field trip to Chicago last week. Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Choice A:<n>Rationales:<n>#### Choice B:<n>Rationales:"getting in trouble" is the opposite of "good trouble" or the good type of trouble. It is better for us to "get in trouble" for fighting for our freedom, for justice and other worthwhile causes. So I disagree. Choice A is not the right answer.<n>#### Choice C:<n>RationalesC. does not always happen when "panic" is the cause of the murder/slaughter of people.<n>#### Choice D:<n>Rationales<n>#### Choice E:<n>RationalesThe right choice is "C" because "C" is not always true that "murder" does happen.<n><n>### Exercise:<n>#### Choice C<n>C. does not always be true that "mass hysteria" would kill people.<n>

If it does, make a true statement. If it doesn’t make sense, make a false statement. 566<n><n>### Statement: You can do more than what is possible. 72<n><n>### Explanation:  <n>Reason: You can’t do more than what is supposed to be done.. If you can’t it doesn’t follow..<n><n>### Statements that make sense are TRUE.<n><n>### Statments that don’t make sense are FALSE.<n><n>#### FALSE<n>Answer: FALSE<n><n>#### TRUE<n>Answer: TRUE

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What would something be if you do not need it? Choices:  A: satisfied B: unnecessary C: luxury D: sufficient E: extra<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: <n><n>### Input::How long do you plan on taking for this question? Choices: 5 min 5 min, or 20 min<n><n>### Response::<n><n>Answer:

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A: persia B: table C: living room D: house E: desk<n><n>### Response:		The mother was worried about the spills, so I bought a rug under the "desk".<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The answer "A: persian rug B: table rug C: living room rug D: house rug E: desk rug" is not accurate. The rug is not a "desk rug." "Desk" could not be replaced by "under"; the words would not fit together in a sentence.<n><n>### Input:"Where do they go" can be replaced by another expression which makes the statement complete. Choices:  A B C D E F G H<n><n>### Response:"They go to the market!"<n><n>### Expectation:This answer is a complete answer that makes the statement true. The sentence, "Where do the puppies go," may sound like a question at first, but the speaker gives an answer to the question in the way an answer to a question would sound.<n><n>### Examine:<n>Choices (A)through (F) could be possible completions to the sentence, but only choice (H) makes the sentence true. Choice (H) is not the only possible choice. There might be more options.<n><n>### Choice (E):<n><n>### Choose this choice for part of the explanation because: E is a possible completion, but it is not a complete and true answer to the question. In fact, that answer to the question will make it false.<n><n>### Notice:<n>The choices are "puppies" and "puppies", so they can each be singular or plural words. Choice (C), "go into", is a wrong answer because it does not answer any of the sentences. Choice (D), "go to their home," needs to be rewritten as, "They go to their homes," and choice (G), "go to their house," needs to be revised as, "They go into their homes."<n><n>### Expected answer:<n>The expected answer is "they go into their homes".<n><n>### Choices (G)- (I):<n><n>### Describe and explain:<n>These are all wrong choices. Choice (G) needs to be rewritten.<n><n>### Explain:<n>These are both wrong choices because they make the sentence false.<n><n>## Practice problems<n><n>### Instructions:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		C: Alike<n><n>### Rationale:In a similar relationship, the difference (of a quantity) from a given quantity, may have no other difference. For example, 2x - 2 = 0<n><n>### Similar equations: In math, similar functions are expressions that are related to each other by some scalar multiple or by an affine transformation (see homomorphism of vector spaces).<n><n>### Alike word search:<n><n>Similar to, or like in form, nature, or character.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: <n><n>### Input-Exercise<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following True or False question.<n><n>## Input:<n>Brenda walked to the park 1 block away and rode her bicycle 3 blocks away. Choices: 1: A:$68.00 2: B:$63.81 3: C:$60.70 4: D:$66.50 5: E:$3.81<n><n>### Input<n>Answer: $3.81<n>#### Answer Key:<n>Input: On his first day at work, Tim was told that He would have $68 for his travel allowance, that the taxi ride from the offices to his apartment was $0.29 more than the average cost of taxi ride for previous trips to the train station which was $0.28, how much is the taxi ride from his home to his offices?<n>To find the Taxis ride: Trip1 from apartment to office costing $0.28$0.28 + Add $0.29$0.29 = $0.57$0.57 or 57cents. Now subtract $68 - 57$68-57 = $1.26$1.26 or 126 cents.<n>#### 1.26<n>Answer: Trip1 $0.57 and Trip2 $1.26<n>#### A) $0.57 B) $1.26 C) $63.81 D) $60.70 E) $3.81 <n><n><n>### Input -Ask the question<n>Choose the answer that best completes the sentence.<n><n>### Response-Write your answer<n>In five years, Mike will be 44 years older than today.<n><n>### <n>### Demonstation<n>Janet has 9 cards fewer than Brenda. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is an way for people to meet with each other? Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A: believe in god<n>2. B: pay bills<n>3. C: group together<n>4. D: enjoy themselves<n>5. E: face each other

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What does exercising immediately lead to? Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A:Relaxation<n><n>exercise + Exercise + Work + Work => relaxation<n><n>### Output:<n><n>B: Exhaustion<n>The response does not use the correct punctuation, which will lead to the exercise session.<n><n>### Input :What does exercising<n><n>### Response :Immediately lead to:<n><n>What does exercising ===>>>> <<<<<<< lead to? Choices : A:relaxation B:exhaustion C:dangerous. D:stronger E:strong<n><n>### Output :<n><n>C: Exhaustion, dangerous<n><n>exercise = ==>>>>> exercise or exercise + exercise or exercise + Dangerous<n><n>### Input <==>> exercise what does it mean<n><n>```python<n>1st:<n>exercise = 4 - 4 - 7 + 4 + 5 + 2 - 3 - 8<n><n>2nd:<n>Exercise ===> exercise or: exercise ===> exercise<n>```<n><n>### Output <==>> exercise what it means<n><n>```python<n>Answer: Answer ===> what it means<n><n>Exercising mean<n>what means = exercise<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:There is a lot of sugar in what food that fits in your hand? Choices:  A: cupboard B: chocolate C: coffee D: candy bar E: soda pop<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer to the question about the quantity of sugar in what food is cupboard because sugar is produced in an agricultural setting of plants like sugarcane or sugar beets.<n><n>### Justification:<n>There are different types of sugar which are either in liquid which are called sugar syrup or granular which is commonly called sugar.<n><n>### The main source of sugar is:<n><n>* (1) from sugarcane<n>* (2) from sugar beet<n><n>### The production of sugar is based on: (1) from sugar cane (2) In sugar beet and<n><n>```text<n>#Cane sugar<n><n>- from sugar cane<n><n>#Beet sugar #<n>In beets<n><n>```<n><n>### A process of refining sugar is:<n><n>The process of refining sugar begins with the mill process. During that process, sugar cane or sugar beets plant byproducts and mineral by-products to remove the sugar from the juice.<n><n>### Cane Sugars vs Beet Sugars<n><n>Cane sugar refers to sweet in the form of crystals that is not mixed with any kinds of chemicals or additives. In fact, it is made directly from sugar canes.<n><n>Beet sugar refers to sweet in crystal form in which the beets are used as the source. Beet sugar is made from chemicals and additives and thus it is different from cane sugar which is made directly by sugar canes.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The band enjoyed their success and fans, they loved to what at the start of every concert? Choices:  A: hear crowd go mad B: working hard C: clap D: reproduce E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:The band enjoyed their successe and fans, they loved 4/5 (A) hearc crowd go mad.<n><n>### Rationales: The correct answer to a similar question was given.<n><n>### Input:"The answer is always one more than the previous answer, and the next question is always one less than the previous question. "<n><n>### Rationale:The previous question's answers will always be the same.<n><n>### Question #1:<n><n>**Input:** The first question was 0+5=1.<n><n>**Response:** 1.<n><n><n>### Question#2:<n><n>**Input**: The second question was 1+5=6.<n><n>**Response**: 6.<n>\end{code}<n><n>Comment: Looks like we both came up with the same answer for one question for this same test.<n><n>Answer: https://practice.geeksforgeeks.org/problems/count-primes-up-to-limit/1/<n><n>\begin{code}<n>/**<n> * Count of primes upto n<n> */<n>  public List<Integer> primeFactors (int n ) {<n>    List<Integer> ans=new ArrayList<Integer>();<n><n>    for (int i = 2; i <= n; i++) {<n>        for (int j = 2; j <= i / i; j++) {<n>            if ( i % j == 0 ) {<n>              if ( (! ans.contains (i/j)) ) {<n>                ans.add (i/j);<n>              }<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>}<n>\end{code}[1](https://practice.ap-gdm.eu/geeksforgeeks/problems/count_primes_up_to_limit/demo/).<n><n>Comment: This is actually the answer to a completely different problem from the question.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:We want to try some new barbecue sauces, where should we buy some? Choices:  A: detroit B: australia C: michigan park D: cafe E: retail store<n><n>### Response:		<n>E: retail store<n>Input:Pete said to his friend,"Do you want to go out and eat pizza or do you want to go home and make some."<n>Demonstration:To make pizza you need to "out."<n><n>### Rationales:You have to go out to make pizza and "out" is part of the verb word.<n>If you want to go home to make pizza you do not have to go "out."<n><n>#### Answer:E<n>Response:E: retail store
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		A: lake<n>### Instruction<n>Answer the following questions.<n><n>What kind of body is a lake?<n>Answer: a lake is a body of water that is smaller than an ocean.<n><n>Which of these body's of water is deep? Explain why.<n>Answer: A: lake<n>A lake is a body of that is typically shallow water because it has little depth, while the other four have a significant amount of depth.<n>### Demonstion:<n>#### Lake<n><n>Lake is the type of the body of water that is typically shallow.<n><n>#### Oceans<n><n>Oceans are the type of the body that is deep.<n><n>#### Swimming Pools<n><n>Swimming Pool can be shallow or deep depends on the pool.<n><n>#### Ponds<n><n>Ponds are usually shallow and contain some fish.<n><n>#### Childrens Pools<n><n>Childrens Pool is shallow because it is designed for the children to touch the bottom while swimming.<n><n>#### 2<n><n>Answer: Lake<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The explorers found a central passage, much to their delight it led straight to the ancient buried what? Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The arena.<n><n>### Input;How many pearls did Alice buy? Choices: 1. 13 2. 14 3. 15 4. 16 5. 17 6. 18 7. 19 8. 20 9. 21 10. 22 11. 23 12. 24 13. 25 14. 26 15. 27 16. 28 17. 29 18. 30 <n><n>### Response<n><n>14 pearls<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Describe in steps the procedure you would use to answer a problem.<n><n>### Response/Comments<n><n>-The first step is to divide the number by 2 because the question starts with (14 + 14), if we divide it by 2 like in (14/2) 12 then we would get the rest.<n>-The second step would be to put the 10/2 = 5 so we find the total number of pears we would get, we get 14+14 = 28 after adding 5/2 = 2  we get 26 the final answer.<n><n>### Steps for the Answer<n><n>-Find 3 times 4 by following this procedure, divide 4 first, 1 × _____ = 3 2 × _____ = 6 3 × _____ = 9 then take the last number 12<n>-We have now found all the steps and we get the answer for 3 times 4 = 20<n><n>### Solution<n><n>This is the solution for 3 times 12, 3 × 12 = 36<n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>-Conclude as you see fit.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The banjo finds it's history in the Caribbean, but it's probably most famous where? Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input : What is the area of this rectangle? Use 3² x 5² for the first two questions<n><n>### Response : 45<n><n>Answer: 2×3×5 = 30.<n>Area = h (b) = 15.<n>Therefore, Area = 2×3×30 + 2×3×15 = <<2×3×100+2×3×18=14+2×36=10=100>>100.<n>#### 14+2×28=7+56=63=100<n><n>### Answer: 100<n><n>

If they total 21, what are they?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>Answers:14 and 9 (32 total)<n>```<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a sentence that has the phrases from the picture as its subject and objects.<n><n>### Image<n><n>![](images/PossessivePronouns(2).PNG)<n><n>### Image Description<n><n>There could be as many subjects as there are phrases shown, as long as each phrase is the subject or an object.<n><n>### Example<n><n>**Example Sentence #1:** The boy of the boy and the girl can run.<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>**Example Sentences #1 and #2:** The subject and the object have both phrases.<n><n>### Inputs and Outputs<n><n>In this activity, the input and output will be picture with phrases to form sentences.<n><n>### Output<n>The output will be an image without the phrases as the sentences.<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n>### Input <n>```<n>Two lines are shown on the picture. Which lines?<n>```<n><n><n>### Answer<n>```<n>A. lines 1 and 2; B. line 1; C. lines 1 and line 2; D. line 2. <n>```<n><n>## Demonstion<n><n>### 2021-22 Student Handbook<n><n>### Input/Output<n><n>The instructions here explain what the input is and what the output is.<n><n>Here, in the student handbook, input is the description of the document. The output is an image of the document.<n><n>### Picture Description<n><n>Student Handbook 2021 -2022<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>After reviewing and annotating this handbook document to make the notes on it more useful to you, save it as an image file with the 2021 & 2022 handbook name and then upload your image as your response.<n><n>### Annotation<n><n>The annotations are instructions in this handbook.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: smell smoke B: catch cold C: burnt D: look angry E: bank savings<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Input: A: smell smoke<n>Rationales: When the oven is on, the smell of smoke would exist when the pizza is opened one hour after it is put in. Choice A would be correct.<n><n>### Input<n>When the person turned the oven off? Choices: A: turn on fan B: open window C: turn off burner D: bake pizza<n><n>The person then turned the burner off, turned on a fan, and opened a window.<n><n>### response<n>C<n><n>The person turned the burner off after turning the oven on.<n><n>###  Rationales<n>Then, he turned on a fan and opened a window. So, the options are eliminated.<n><n>### input: A cowboy rode a bull once in a rodeo. Later, he rode a bull at a barbeque. Which bull did he ride first?<n>Choices: A: biceps B: left arm C: left thigh D: left back<n><n>### Response<n><n>A<n><n>Answer: The options are eliminated except C and D. Since C and D are about left arm, he rode the left arm first. D would be better.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>He rode the bull at a barbecue. So, he rode the bull at the barbecue first and then in a rodeo.<n><n>### Then, he rode a biceps at a barbeque? Choices:<n><n>### Choices:<n>A: rodeo B: rode a biceps C: rode a bull<n><n>### Response.<n><n>### D<n><n>Answer:  If he rode a bicep in a barbeque, that would be in a rodeo, not a barbeque. B would be the right answer.<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following sentence completion question.<n><n>You might say, "You look like ______."<n><n>### Demostrations<n>The following two pictures show various ways you might say, "You are _____ in the sun" to the person.<n><n>![](pics/picture37.png)<n><n>![](pix/picture38.png)<n><n>### Which sentence does the person in the pictures most likely hear?<n><n>###

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What could happen to you after you see some beautiful clouds above you? Choices:  A: plain B: cold C: dull D: bad E: wet<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Input: The bus trip from Boston to New York takes 3.5 hours. How many hours will it take to drive that same distance? Answer choices:<n><n>1. 2/3 5/2 3 0<n>2. 512/512 2 31/24=2/3 3 1<n><n>### Response<n>2<n><n>### Conclusion/Evidence:<n>Input: 15 + 2/3 = 3/2<n><n>### Response/Critique:I am getting (15): 7+<5/6> = 7+<3/3 - 1/2> = 7+2/3 = 10<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Input: Jan bought $3.69 worth of pencils. She spent 22 cents in coins. How much money did she have left?<n>Rationales<n><n>### Response1:48<n><n>### Explanation:<n>22 cents =.22$<n>3.69 -.22c =.6995$<n>100c/.6995c = 137 (rounded)c<n>.6995c/3.69 =.2394 (rounded)<n><n>### Response2:50c<n><n>### Exploration2:<n><n>Input: Linda bought a hat for $4.97 and used a 20% off coupon when she checked out. How much money did Linda save?<n>Rationales3:<4.97-4.97*20/100> =1.9113 (rounded)3<n><n>### RESPONSE3: 28c<n><n>### Conjecture:<n><n>Input: It has been reported that all 31 of the top sunglasses were 2 7/8inches. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		A, B, D<n><n>Rationales: Jewelry box or boutiques are too small for a choker, while jewelry stores are way too big. Boutiques sell jewelry related items while stores sell jewelry only!<n><n>### Input 2:To find $2 worth of change from 7 nickels and 6 quarters how many dimes would you need?<n><n>Rationales:$2 = 6x.25 +7x.25 + 4x<n><n>$ = 6x. 25/2 +7x.29 +4x/2 = <<6x. 29/2+7x.29+4x/2=20/2>>20/2= 10/ 2 = <<10/2=4>>4 dimes<n><n>Therefore, 4 is the answer.<n><n>### Input3:Penny has the biggest sand castle in the contest. Who has the 3rd biggest?<n><n>Rationaleses:3rd biggest = Penny – 1 (Penny has the largest, so the next largest must be Penny -1)<n><n>### Input4:The largest 4 digit number that is divisible by 3 is?<n><n>Rationalse:3 divides by 3, and we can keep dividing by 3 until it does not.<n>Example:751=3*250+3=3*1*250+1=3*101+1<n><n>751/3 = 250/3 = 188/3 = 62/3 = <<62/3=20>>20<n><n>Therefore, the answer is 20 in this case.<n><n>###Input 5:How many 5s are there in 95?<n><n>Rationalese:95 = 61 + 34<n><n>95 / 5 = <<95/5=19>>19 4s.<n><n>Therefore, there are 19 4s in 95.<n><n>### Output 1:If you have 2 pennies, 3 dimes, and 4 quarters, how many ways can you make a total of $3.7

How many years would it take him to eat 100 pieces of gum every day?<n><n>### Response 2:<n>I calculated 9600/100 = 96 which means it would take 96 years.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		<n>If your answer is E, then what happens to your grapes?<n><n>#### B<n>1. Do you put the grapes in their original packaging to check out? In what?  Is the packaging the grapes were originally in the fruit basket?<n>2. If the packaging of the grapes was changed, where do you put them? In what?  In what do you wrap the grapes?  <n><n>#### D<n>1. Does a fruit basket store the grapes as you would see them in the super market?  Does a fruit basket contain the original packaging of the gapes? Does a fruit basket contain fruit packaging at all?  Does a fruit market contain fruit packaging in the fruit market at all?  What do the packaging options, if any, represent?<n><n>### Analysis:<n>If the packaging of the fruit is changed in one context, then how does that change in packaging affect the context in which the grapes are stored?<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The evacuation became mandatory, so what came on the TV? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Learning languages is difficult.  Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>|Choice|Explanation|<n>|---|---|<n>|A|Causes the person to overthink the communication and creates confusion.|<n>|B|Immersive environments create an opportunity for miscommunications, resulting in overthought, and frustration on both sides of the immersion.|<n>|C|It becomes more awkward to speak the language without making a mistake.|<n>|D|Immersion, like any other situation, may result in people misinterpreting one another's intentions.|<n>|E|Miscommunications and misinterpretations may result in headaches later on or even now.|<n><n>### Option: Write two more correct responses.<n><n>Response 2: The immersion of communication may result in someone feeling overwhelmed, frustrated, and insecure. Immersion, like any communication medium, can cause misinterpretation on both ends and make communication awkward.<n><n>Response 3: Someone may become discouraged if they don't learn quickly enough, causing them to be confused and think about the interactions.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:They decided to hash things out over drinks, after enough booze they were able to get close on a few things and what? Choices:  A: reach tentative agreement B: suicide C: examine thing D: commit murder E: stay in bed<n><n>### Response:		B: suicide<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple answer.<n><n>### Input:"What is 2018 divided by 7?"<n><n>### Response:"\<n>### Instrucciones:Responde a la siguiente pregunta con la cantidad que contiene al menos uno de los primeros tres términos de la división:<n><n>### Respuesta:4<n><n>### Insturctions: What is the answer to a question asking "if you add 6 to a number between 6 and 12, what is the answer?" Choices: A: 18 B: 8 C: 10 D: 14 E: 12<n><n>### Input"When you add 6 to any number between 6 and the first square root of 10, the answer is between 12 and 16. What is the first square root of?"<n><n>### Answer: 7<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question:What is the sum of 39999, 52341, and 13794? Choices: A: More than 99 B: 19195 C: 14133 D: 17996 E: 17770<n><n>### Instuctions:Respond with the sum of 3 answers from the choices.<n><n>### Response4,598<n><n>### Insturation:Respond with the answers to the multiple choice.<n><n>### Answer4,598; 1413,3; and 17997<n><n>### Instuictions:What is 728 ÷ 12? Choices: A: A: 61 B: 61 C: 57 D: 55 E: 50.875<n><n>### Response57<n><n>### InputHow many quads are there in 4252?Choices: A: 2 B: 10 C: 13 D: 12 E: 4<n><n>### AnswerChoices: D: 12<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. A  average is when you collect 3(or some number) amounts and divide by that.<n>So the temperature from Seattle during August would be 3 amount divided by 3 amount to get the average.<n>Then plug in the data to get the answer.<n><n>### Rationales<n>We need 3 amounts of data. We need a temperature value for Seattle in August to be able to add up the data. We need to divide by the amounts we gathered from Seattle in August to get the average. In this case, since we do not have a temperature value, we will have to estimate it.<n><n>Input: What is required to be good in math? Choices: A: practice B: knowing your times tables C: a computer D: knowing everything E: your teacher<n><n>### Response E<n><n>#### 94<n>Answer: E<n><n>Input: What month will come before September? A: calling a doctor B: placing an order over the Internet C: buying plane tickets D: applying for a cell phone service E: checking out at the bookstore<n><n>### Answer E<n><n>#### 59<n>Answer: E<n>We can call a doctor, apply for a cellphone service, placing an order over the internet, buying plane tickets, and checking out from a bookstore with a 5-digit phone number. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:James felt himself losing consciousness. If the number of cards that Janet and Mara have in all is at least 472, how many cards does Brenda have?<n><n>### Demostration :- <n>Rationale: <n>We need to first find the total number of cards they have, then we solve the second question which asks for the number of cards brenda has.<n><n>We consider the cards as a set, that means if we know how many cards there are, we can find how many elements are there, and if we know the number of elements, we can find every element.<n><n>Therefore, we will find the number of cards they have in all<n><n>If we do it as a logical problem it will go as below ;-<n> <n>Number of cards they have = 9+8 = 17 <n><n>Number of cards that Brenda have = 17 -9 = 8<n><n><n>#### 17<n>Answer: 17<n><n>### Input :-You start at your home and want to reach your workplace. Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n><n>### Response:		C<n>\[{\underline{\text{D = D = }}E}\]<n><n>\[{\underline \text{D = D=A}}\]<n><n>\[E=H=G+F=G+F+R+A+S+B+D+N=G+F+E+C+B+N=A_{11+11+3+3+2+7+2+1}={\frac{16+2+3}{2}}={16+1+1}\]<n><n>Therefore, c<n><n>### 151<n><n>### A:<n><n>```python<n>if x * 10 == 82:<n>    print(x*10)<n>    print(x/10)<n>```<n><n>### B:<n><n><n>```python<n>print(18/20)<n>```<n>### C:<n><n>```python python<n>if x < 36:<n>    print(23*x)<n>```<n><n><n>### D:<n><n>```python <n>if y >=0 and y<=20: <n>    print(y)<n>else:<n>        print("Sorry you can't use this website")<n>```<n><n>## Input<n><n>Cruz bought 1/5 of the pizza at the restaurant last night. "))<n>num_girl = int(input("And how many girls? "))<n>total_people, total_pizza = 1 + num_guy + num_girl, (num_guy+num_girl)*(num_guy+2)/2<n>```<n><n>## Task 3<n>Write a program that asks the name and age of people. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a bee gathering pollen? Choices:  A: united states B: sky C: court D: field of flowers E: orchard<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instruct a friend:Ask a friend to answer the question and complete the task shown above.<n><n>### Rationales: Answer A is the correct answer since the orchard is a field of flowers, meaning bees gather pollen there.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### 2 or more people have to complete the task shown above:<n><n>### Rationale: Task A: Mara has 3 times as many points as Bob. How many points does Mara have if Bob has 96 points more than her? <n>#### Bob<n><n>Rationales: Bob has 96 so:<n>Mara has 3 × 96 = <<3*96=288>>288 points, and 288 is 8 points more than 280.<n>### 280<n>Answer: 280<n> <n>#### 2 or more people complete the task shown above, and each person gets the same amount of points by their answer:<n>Marco and Dustin both correctly answer that Marco has twice as many points as Dustin, but Marco has 90 points while Dustin has 80, Marco should get twice as many points by their answer, 180, but Marco only got 90, Dustin got the right answer of 80.<n>## Task B:<n>1232<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. Write the answer as the ratio of 8 to 4.<n><n>12 × 9 + 11<n><n>129/11<n><n>56/5<n><n>Different ways to subtract are to use an addition-subtract property, the distributive property, and then a subtract property.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: 12×6+11÷6<n><n>Rationales: We will use the associativity property, the distributive properties, and subtract properties.<n><n>#### 209/12<n>Answer: 209/4<n>Input: 11×4-11.6÷2<n><n>Rationales to be used: The associative property, the distributive with subtraction, and the subtract property.<n><n>#### 132/16<n>Answer: 132/32<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: What part of the number 920 will be 1,090 when you multiply it by 3? The process that is used to identify candidates for jobs in an organization is called candidate selection.<n><n>### D:Not right.<n>Not right: The purpose of giving job related training is to develop the skills and the knowledge needed by an employee in order to perform his or her job.<n><n>### E:Not right.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is done to wood to attach something to it? Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		B: carved<n><n>### Rationale:The verb is "to carve".<n><n><n>### InputThe train is 6 miles from the bus garage. The bus is 24 miles from the subway station. To solve, find the mile between train and subway and multiply it by 2 to get the total distance from bus and train. Then get the total distance the traveler needs to ride to get home.<n><n>### ResponseThe train is 6 from the bus garage and the bus is 24 from the subway station, so the bus is 2x the distance of the train. Also, the bus is 2 miles from the subway train, so the train and bus are 4 miles apart. Therefore, to get from the train to the bus, one needs ride 4 + 2 = <<4+2=6>> miles.<n>To get home, the total distance needed is train + subway + home = 6 + 24 + 1 = <<6+24+1=31>>31 miles.<n><n><div class='figures'><n>* A: The train is 6 miles away from the bus garage.<br><n>Average length of train: 6/3 = 1/3<br><n>Average distance: 1/3<n>---<n>* A: The bus is 4 miles away from the subway train.<n>---<n>* B: The bus is 2 miles away from the substation.<n></div><n><n>### InputRon is the only person you can call a friend. Tom thinks Ron might like to eat his specialty.<n>Input: Tom thinks Ron might like a snail. Rationales: Ron is the only person you could call a friend.<n>Tom thinks Ron might like to dine on snails.<n><br><n>* A: Ron wants a snack.<n>---<n>* A' Ron wants to eat.<n>---<n>* C: Ron likes a snail.<n>---<n></div><n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is likely to have more than one level in a city? Choices:  A: carpenter's shop B: video game C: garage D: total number E: building<n><n>### Response:		The building in the city has many levels.<n><n>Input: How many ounces of butter did he get? He spent half of that.How much ounces left did he buy? Answer is...<n><n>### Response : A container with 9 ounces. He spend half of that He spent 9-(1/2 of 9). He spent 4.5 ounces of buter. He now has 4.5-4.5=0.0 of butter.<n><n>Input: What is the sum of 17 and 4? <n><n>### Response 17+4=21<n><n>Input: What number is 1/5 of 2/3 of 9/10?<n><n>### Response A: 3/4 of 9/14.<n><n>Input: She walked 10 blocks to school and then rode 73 blocks on the bus. How many blocks did she walk in all?<n><n>### A. 73 Answer: 173<n><n>Input: There are 24 cookies and 12 packages. How many packages of cookies are in all?<n><n><n>###Answer: 24<n><n>Input: He sold a shirt and pants. He received 25 dollars for the shirt. He received 20 dollars for the pants. How much money did he earn in all? Round to the nearest dollar.<n><n>###Answer:: 45 dollars<n><n>Input: There were two dogs when the game started. The number of dogs increased by four. How many dogs were there at the end of the game?<n><n>###A: 6<n><n>Input: Which number is greater: 35 - 26 or 15 - 7?<n><n>###Answer : 35 -26 is greater<n><n>Input: What multiple of 4 is 36?<n><n>### Answer : 36=12<n><n>Input: She had two times as many books as a brother. She had 150 less books than her brothers. How many books were they together?<n><n>###145.5<n><n>Input: In 1850 there 100000 people. By 1860 they were 10 times as many. What was the number.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:John and Jane were a couple.  They were dating for a while and wanted to be together for even longer. For this reason, they did what? Choices:  A: make sex B: plan to marry C: dance D: electrical circuit E: row about<n><n>### Response:		C<n>### Answer:C<n>C: Dance<n>### Input:<n>This text, which is a sentence composed of 15 words and letters,<n>contains 21 letters and begins with the letter M<n>Rationales:This text, which is more than 15 words and less than 15 letters,<n>begins with the letter M and<n>ends with the letter Y<n>Most likely this text is:<n>Human<n>#### 26 <n>Answer: Human<n><n>### Input ☐<n>☐This letter is an anagram.<n>☐The letter contains two anagrams.<n>#### 13<n>Answer: 13<n>### Instruction ☑<n>☑Write a response that appropriately fills in the blank.<n>☑Write an appropriate response in place of the underlined portion.<n><n>### A sentence should be completed by doing what ☐.<n>☐adding more information ☐<n>expanding what has been said<n><n>### This is an inference ☐. Which is a type of inference ☐<n><n>☐The type of inference is_______________<n>Which is a type of inference is :<n>an inference by an educated guess<n><n>#### 16<n>Answer: an inference by an educated guess (type of inference)<n><n>### Instructions ⑤<n><n>⑤Write a response that appropriates completes the instructions.<n><n>### Given:John works at a garage.  On February John found two parts that he needed<n>to finish repairs.  John’s assistant told John that he could not help John fix<n>the car.John’s assistant told John to_______, to do these things.<n>#### 14<n>Answer: find parts<n>### Instruciton ②<n>②The instruction  reads,<n>Given:On February John, who works at a garage, found two parts that he<n>needed to fix his car.  John’s mechanic told him to ②<n>#### 12<n>Answer: fix his car<n>### Instrucution ②<n><n>②Write a response that appropriatly completes the instruction.<n><n>### Input<n>Given:John and Jane were in a heated argument
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What do you get for not moving your car during the required time? Choices:  A: towed B: accidents C: driving D: getting tired E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		___<n><n>Rationales: This is a trick question. Since B and C cover the same answer (accidents), A and E are the only two choices not covered by that answer. So B, E, and C are eliminated and A and D are the possible answers.<n>CORRECT D<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### C<n>

Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Rationales: <n><n>#### 52<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following sentences.<n><n>### <n>Input:How much will two more than four times a number cost?<n>Rationales::<n><n>### Demosrtion:<n><n>### 48<n>Answer: 48<n><n>### Demolution:<n><n>Two more than four times a given number is less than 56, so:<n>* The number x + 2 is less than 58.<n>* Four x + 8 is less than 54<n>* Four (58-8) + 8 is $5.<n>Therefore, two more than four times the number is less than $5.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The number y is at least two more than 1/7 of the number x.<n>The number y is less than 2/7 of x.<n>The largest positive integer less than x is 2/7 of it.<n>The greatest two integer less than x = 14.<n>Therefore, the number y is less than [14:14](https://www.google.com/search?q=14:14&rlz=1C1VFKB_enUS747US747&ei=6hA6XuX3MMyQsALu75iYBg&oq=14:&gs_l=psy-ab.3..0.216774..216777...0.1.1.7i84...5.0..0.0.1....344.344.1j1j1....0...1..gws-wiz..0.1.144.jLvMHB8Qg48) = 21.<n><n>### Inputs:Rewrite the following as a ratio.<n><n>### Ratio:The ratio of the product of two numbers is to the sum of the first number is 2 to the ratio of the second number is three.<n><n>### Demo:<n>The ratio of the product is 8 to the sum is 4.<n>The sum to the product is 8 : 4

You paid a dollar extra at the coffee shop for your refill. How much change do you have? (Don't include the dollar you spent at the coffee shop.)<n><n>### Solution<n>Your total money you spent was $17 + $8 + $1 = <<$17+$8+$1=17>>17 and your change would be the $17 - 1 = <<$16.99>>16.99.<n><n>### Solution 2<n>$17 + $8 - 1 = <<17+8-1=17.9>>17.9<n><n>### Solution3<n>$17 + 8 -9.9 = <<17+17.9>>27<n><n>### How many gallons of milk do you buy? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where are people likely to stand at an intersection? Choices:  A: cars B: city street C: street corner D: fork in road E: at a red light<n><n>### Response:		C) <n><n>### Rationales:<n>People in cars are likely to stand at an intersections as it's the easiest route to travel and requires one of the smallest turns to get from point A to B.<n><n>### Answer:A) cars<n><n>### Response<n>This is incorrect.<n><n>### Why:<n>This response is incomplete without a statement of why this option is the best choice.<n><n>### Input;<n>Where are people likely to place their money for the best return on their investment? Choices: 1. A: 6.5% B: 7.5% C: 8.5% D: 9.5% E: 21.0%<n><n>### Response;C)<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The highest return you'll get with a 10 thousand investment is 21.0%. This will give the largest return with no risk.<n><n>### Rationals:<n><n>### Input<n>Choices: B) A, B, C, D, E: A)<n><n>### Response <n>This is correct.<n><n>### rationale<n>You chose the answer lettered A.<n><n>[![Analysis video](https://img.shields.io/badge/analysis-youtube-f8c443?style=social&logo=reddit "Analysis video")](/videos/6-a3Vs5gOoQ-qrq5pSqz527w/)<n><n>### rationals video<n>[![Analysis rationals video](https://img2.shields.ioplc5.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com/videos/7-Bd38UVZk8G2sKsxD7Yy-w.jpg?logo=youtube "Analysis rationals")](/videos/7-5YU-rFQd206_CmF7X4hTQ/)<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:John moved away from his family.  He was a bit upset that he had to do it, but he needed the job.  Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>John moved away from his home; and since he was upset the job was the one he had to work. So he wanted to have it available to move back home.<n><n>### Rationale<n>- A: Present = This word has a meaning the time (present) you are living now and not the point of time when you left.<n>- B: Stray here = Stray it is a word used to describe a way a animal go or run in a place.<n>- C: Closer = This word implies something that's near you.<n>- D: available = It's not used in the sentence.<n>- E: Come herE = This word has a mean to go or arrive in a place.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n><n>### Input <n>We have the following table that show the results of 20 trials.<n><n>###  Input<n>Round 5 to the nearest whole number.<n><n>### Input of the problem<n><n>### Input a.<n><n>### Output answer<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: study french cooking C: taste sauce D: prepare food E: thin sauce<n><n>### Response:		D is the correct answer<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The correct answer, D, could be logically ruled out based on the choices.<n>B doesn't mention the evening. Choice B is not correct.<n>C could have been a valid answer, but if choice E was not given, a test taker who didn't know the correct answer might have chosen E. It is also unnecessary information to mention that the chef tastes sauce. It could be omitted. The only answer that the choice can reasonably be deduced from is _prepare food_.<n><n>####<n>Answer: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:After his mother saw his report card he knew he was going to be doing housework, what could have prevented this? Choices:  A: sneezing B: fatigue C: house clean D: feeling satisfied E: getting good grades<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Incorrect:  A: snotty B: house clean C: sneezing D: getting good grades E: fatigue<n>Explanation:The correct choice is E. The last box means getting good grades which would have prevented that situation.<n><n>### Correct:  E: fatigue<n>The grades were not good enough that the mother will be satisfied with a good grade.<n><n>### Incorrect Answer:<n>### Incremental: snotty B. house clean D. getting good grades<n>Explanation:<n><n>### Immediate:  E. fatigue Choices: Incremental: A. Sneezy B. house clean C. getting good grades D. sneezing<n><n>### Improved Answer:<n>### Feedback:<n>Incorrect:  C: house clean B: snotty D: getting good grates E: fatigue<n><n>### Correct Answer:  E: fatigu<n><n>### Explanation:<n>-Fatigue- physical tiredness<n>-Sneezy- in the process of sneezing<n>-Snotty- characterized by sneezes or sniffles<n><n>Answer: Fatigue<n><n>### Increments and Feedback:<n>Sneezy can be removed as it is not a choice<n>Snotty can be removed as well because it is a character as opposed to a choice<n>Getting good grades doesn't affect how people react hence it can go<n>House cleaning affects how they react hence it can go as well<n><n>### Improvements:<n>Fatigue can be removed because there is no evidence that people would react like that<n><n>### Images that might Help:<n>![](https://drive.google.com/uc?export=view&id=1wfEUUzgYk0Df0RV4nZWCzgKJ_z0vHxVt)<n>![](https://i.imgur.com/UHQbZ5R.png)<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:James chose to not to print the cards, because he wanted to be more personal. What type of cards did he choose, instead? Choices:  A: cursive writing B: hand writing C: store bought D: online media E: hand written<n><n>### Response:		He chose to print the cards in cursive writing.<n>

Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		Notoriety<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Answers: __________A: notoriety____________<n>________________Bem: emotional distress________________<n>________________C: Riot________________<n>________________D: bad dreams__________________<n>________________E: annoyance__________________<n><n>### Solution:<n>C<n><n>### Input<n>>The number of cubic centimeters of volume in a solid sphere of given radius R = r * r * r, where r is the radius of the sphere<n><n>### Rationales<n>R -> Radius<n>C -> Centimeter<n><n>In the 0 - 9 digits, we must know that in the "r" part there are 3 digits.<n><n>The "3" means the result is 3 cubic centimeters, but it is equal to the cubes of the number given above **3**.<n><n>If we subtract the sum of the digits we see<n><n>3 > 2<n>Therefore<n><n>R > C<n><n>### Solution<n><n>C<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>In the following short statement, underline the pronoun that is used to replace the bold underlined word.<n><n>>Jodie and Tim's house is a two story house with seven bedrooms, a bathroom in every room, a kitchen, a laundry, and five bathrooms. Jodie's and Tim's house contains six bedrooms that contain either a queen size or a king size bed, a large wardrobe, and two dressers. The largest room in the house is the master room, the master room has a king size bed and two night stands and a window seat.<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n>For example A, we need in the answer to indicate that the underline with "their" pronoun was used as a subject pronoun for each of the statements.<n><n>Answer: The largest room in the Jodie and Tim' home, is the master bedroom which has a king size bed, and two night stands and one window seat, with two of the bedrooms having a queen sized bed.<n><n>## Input<n>"Which one of the following is not part of a process sequence?<n>A: Taking the temperature<n>B: Reading a temperature chart<n>C: Taking the patient's blood pressure<n>D: Recording the blood pressure in a patient's file"

That's why it's not surprising that they are not learning as much as they should be, and are performing poorly on tests. It has gotten so bad that educators are being considered criminals.<n>Teachers' evaluations are based on how well their students perform on standardized tests and how well their students attend class and complete their classwork and homework. But teachers cannot help students perform well on tests if they refuse to cooperate, and they can't make students attend a class or complete their classwork because students have the freedom to choose.<n>Teaching is a demanding job. The author thinks more education is necessary to keep students out of trouble.<n><n><n>B.The sentence with the incorrect subject-verb agreement

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What would children do if they are bored? Choices:  A: walk B: change shoes C: play tag D: smell smoke E: reach over<n><n>### Response:		D:<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n><n>### Instructions:Follow the instructions to solve the puzzle.<n><n>### Input:(0)<n><n>##><n><n>##><n>##> ##> ### # # # # # ## # # # # # #<n>### # # # # ##  ## # ##  ##  # # # ##<n>## # # # # ##    ##  ##  ##   ## # # # ##<n>   # ## # ## # ## # # # ##   ## ##   ## # ##<n> ## ## ## ## ## ## # ## ## ## ## # #  ## ## ##<n> ## ## ##  ## ## ## # ##  ## ## ## ## #  ## ##<n> ## ##  ##  ## ## ##  ##  # ##  ## # #  ## # #<n>## ## ## ## ##  ##    ## ##  ## ## # # ## # ## ##<n>## # #  ## ## # # # # ## ## ## ## ##  # # # #<n> ## ## #  ##  ##   # ## ## ##  ## # #   ## # ##<n>    ##  ## ##  ##   ##  ## ## ##   ## # #  ##<n>  ##  ## ##  # # ## ### #  ## ##  # ## # ##  ##<n>  ## #  ## ##   ## #   ## ## #   ##   #  ## # ##<n><n>### # #<n>## #<n>### #<n><n>### #<n>###<n><n>###<n><n>#### 100<n>Answer: 100<n><n>### Output:Answer the questions true or false.<n>### # # ## ## ## # # # ## ## # # #<n>## # ## ##  ## ##  ### # # ## #####<n>## ####   ## ##  ##  ######  ##  ##<n># ##   #### ## ## ##  ## ######  ##<n> # ## ## ## ###  ##   ##     ##   ##<n>## # # ##   ##    ##     ##    ##   ##<n>##    ## ##   ##    ##  ##       ##   <n> ##   ## ###  ## #     ##       ## ##   <n>##  # ## ##  ##   ###    ##    ##  ##<n>##    ## #   ##      ##    ##  ## ##<n>   ## ## ##  ##

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What could contain no more than around 100 people? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by only a few people recently? Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Demonstation: If a person was standing directly under a plane, he or she would find air that had been breathed by that person. This is because the air that came into the body is already breathed out, and vice versa.<n>####A<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Instrucation:Complete each task.<n><n>### Input : If there are three bags, each containing a different number of apples, and no two bags contain the same number of apples, which apples are in bag 1? Choices: <n>> A: 3 apples and 4 apples <n>> B: 2 apples and 4 <n>> C: 4 apples and 3 apples <n>> D: 2 apples <n>> E: 4 apples 🤔<n><n>### Response :<n>### Demonstation:<n>1:<n><n>2:<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>1:<n> <n>2:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1:<n>In bag 1, we know that no two bags contain same number of apples and so this bag does not contain any of the remaining apples.<n>2:<n>Apples in bag 2 are in the bags (1 and 3) (because we know bags 1 and 3 contain different apples and bags 1 and2 1 and 3 do not contain the same apples) as we have already considered bag 1.<n><n>3:<n>Because all the apples are in bags 1 and3, bag 4 does not contain any apples.<n>4:<n>We know that all the 4 apples are in baskets 1 and3 and so bag 2 does not contain any appes.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a sign with some people lined up next to it?
