Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The king was to meet an ambassador, where would the meet? Choices:  A: court B: dinning room C: throne room D: monarchy E: castle<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Input:The king was to meeting an ambassador, where will the meet?<n>Rationales:(1)  The monarchy is a kingdom that rules over other kingdoms. <n>(2)  The king is a ruler, not a king.<n>(3)  A king is head of state, not a king. (4)  The king and the monarchy are in England.<n><n>Therefore, answer is (D) in the castle.<n><n>#### C<n><n>##### Answer: C<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>Complete each incomplete statement or draw a flowchart or a pseudo-code for the given statement.<n><n>### Input Description:<n><n>### Response Description:<n><n>## Instrucess:Answer the following multiple choise question.<n><n>## Demo:<n>## Input:How many times does a clock show one number every fourth hour?<n>## Ralations:111 x 16<n><n>#### 111<n>Answer:  111<n><n>## Demonstration:Write an expression or a formula for the following statements.<n><n>### Statement in the form of a sentence:<n>- "Add 3 to a number that is two times a smaller number. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where does a person need to get when they have more kids? Choices:  A: compliments B: understand themselves C: life partner D: second chances E: larger house<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>*Answer: E*<n><n>### Input:(If the person is already at the second step in the task description):Which of these steps should they not take if they want to get the result described in the previous task? The other steps are correct at this point in time.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Riding bike through rough terrain can be dangerous, one could find themselves what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: accident C: get somewhere D: hurt E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationales: Choices from A to E are words that describe dangerous situations when riding a bike. However, this question is about the danger of riding a bike, not riding a bike somewhere. The answer choice is C since the question does not talk about anywhere a person wants to get to while riding a bike; therefore, this is not something that will happen to a person while traveling on a bike.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What does a virus primarily do to a person? Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: reproduce<n><n>### Acknowledgment:<n>Your classmate replied in the forum that "A virus is typically an infectious agent that causes disease within a biological system such as a living organism.... Viruses cannot reproduce alone. They can only reproduce while invading a cell. They cannot eat food but are designed as a parasite that lives within a host."<n><n>### Instructions:Write an original, 5-sentence paragraph (comprehensible to others of similar age) explaining how you use the vocabulary to your advantage.<n><n>### Vocabulary: 25 words related to the unit topics.<n>#### Computers<n>- code<n>- data<n>- encryption<n>- firewall<n>- hack<n>- Internet<n>- malware<n>- phishing<n>- prank<n>- root<n>- security<n><n>#### Security<n>- access control<n>- authentication<n>- authorisation<n>- back door<n>- crack<n>- drive-by download<n>- hacker<n>- keylogger<n>- password<n>- scam<n>- security hole<n>- security risk<n>- spyware<n>- Trojan horse<n>- virus<n><n>#### Hackers<n>- brute force attack<n>- wardriving<n><n>### Instantiation:<n>In the discussion "What did you learn?" you explained that you are aware of the terms "hacker" and "cracking the code." You provided an example of an Internet-related code used to navigate websites, and you mentioned the terms "wiring." You wrote that cracking a code is unlawful and that you will remain as educated as possible to counteract the activities of hackers.<n><n>### Summary:<n>You demonstrated mastery of the vocabulary words to the extent required for grade level. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What is a place that might not always have a queen? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What place is not interesting to children? Choices:  A: classroom B: toy store C: school D: soccer game E: dinner<n><n>### Response:		 A: class;  B: toy;  C: school;  D: soccer game;  E: dinner<n><n>#### Input:  A: class  B: toy  C: school  D: soccer  E: dinner<n>Output:  A: class,  B: toy,  C: school,  D: soccer,  E: dinner<n>Input: Choose which is not. W: All others.<n>Output:<n><n>#### Input: A: B is as tall [B]as tall as<br> B: B is not as <br>as tall as<br><br> C as tall as<br>  D:  Tall<br> E:  Taller<br> F: Tallest<br> G: Same as tallest<br><br> H: Lesser<br> K: Lesser than tall<n>Output:<n><n>**Note:** Write the numbers 1, 2, 3 and so on in that order.<n><n>### Input # 1: Choose which of the following numbers is greater.<n>13<n>17<n>22<n>28<n>31<n>33<n>37<n>44<n>48<n>49<n>53<n>56<n>57<n>61<n>66<n>69<n>76<n>79<n>81<n>85<n>89<n>90<n>94<n>97<n>101<n>104<n>106<n>110<n>117<n>120<n>123<n>130<n>136<n>138<n>140<n>142<n>144<n>146<n>148<n>149<n>150<n>152<n>153<n>156<n><n>#### Output # 1: 28, 136<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What are ai machines known for doing? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:People are purposefully harming others, what trait are they exhibiting? Choices:  A: deceptive B: altruistic C: stupid D: cruel E: agressive<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def check_if_string_is_a_letter(string):<n>    if string == 'a' or string == 'b' or string == 'c' or string == 'd' or string == 'e':<n>        return True<n>    else:<n>        return False<n><n>def string_validation(string):<n>    string1 = "string"<n>    string2 = "a string"<n><n>    if check_if_string__is_a_letter.match(string2):<n>        if check_if_any_string_is_in_a_dictionary.match(string2) == True:<n>            if check_if_the_string_contains_all_of_the_letters_together.match(string2).group() == string:<n>                if check_if_a_number_of_letters_are_in_a_string.match(string2)[0][0] == 2:<n>                    if check_if.match(string1)[0][2] == check_if_the.match(string1) and string1 and -1!= string1[1:4] and 0 < string1[0]:<n>                        string3 = ''<n>                        for char in string1:<n>                            string3 = string3 + char<n>                        return string3<n>                elif check_if_a.match(string1).group() == check_if_all_of_a_dictionary.get(string1):<n>                    if check.match(string1):<n><n>                else:<n>                    return string<n><n>        else:<n>            return string<n>    else:<n><n>        return string<n><n>input1 = 'The world is a mess'<n>if string_validation(input1) == "a is a letter":<n>```<n><n>Answer:<n>```<n>  a<n>```<n><n>### Input : the program will ask the user for their age and then display a statement. Write a statement that the program will present based on the age of the user<n>For ages within the range from 5 to 13 - The user is in the "Tween" ages.<n>For ages within the teen age range - The user is a teenager.<n>Ages outside of the teen (and preteen) age range - The user has reached adulthood.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What does someone want when having fun with their friends and trying to fit in? Choices:  A: being understood B: beer C: playing around D: hug E: visiting friends<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: beer<n><n>### Input<n>The number you are looking for is 1101. If you look at the binary representation of the number 110, notice that the third digit is 1. Now let us calculate the sum of the three binary digits. Notice that the third binary digit is 1, the second one is 0 and the first one is 1. All three of these digits have to be added up. So now, we can think about our number as 111 and our sum is 4 + 1 + 8 = 13. All we have to do is think of all the numbers until 13 (using the binary system). Notice that the number 13 has a 1 in the third position, what about the 2nd number? The number 12 has a zero in the third position, so that is not what we want. The 3rd position is a one, so then we continue with the 123 series. 123 = 3 + 2 + 1 = 6. We take the 1 from the first number, the 3 from the second number and the 6 from the 3rd number to find that the total of the two numbers is: 6 + 3 + 1 + 1 + 6 + 3 = 19. You have found the solution. The answer is 110!<n><n>### Response<n>A is the correct answer in this case. I would have started by writing down the total number of options as 5. I would have then counted the ones that start off with B (4). I would have counted the remaining options to get to E (10). So there are 4 options that do not start off with beer and 10 options that do start with beer (4 + 6). Since the options do not include any of the letters other than B, then the right answer must include at least one B. There are 10 options including B (10 + 4). So if the total number of options is 10 + 4, then the answer must be E. The options are as follows: B, C, A, E, D,F.<n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What can happen to you when eating hamburger from someone that you do not know that does not happen when you usually eat a hamburger? Choices:  A: allergic reaction B: gain weight C: have fun D: heartburn E: food poisoning<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>P11242.zip<n><n>#### <img src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53369711/121788029-b6fc8780-c77b-11eb-8154-01de2e6c3796.PNG"><n>P11263.zip<n><n>#### Allergic reaction <n><n>###

Choices:  One  Three  Nine  Twelve Eight  Thirteen  None<n><n>### Response A:None<n><n>### Demos:<n>Rationales<n>None can be found in 1375*6.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 3<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 9<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 12<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 8<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 13<n><n>### Input. A basketball player takes 18 shots and makes every one. What percentage of shots he makes? Choices: A: 50%  B: 25%  C: 100% D: 75%<n><n>### Response B: 25 %<n><n>### Democession<n><n>Rationales<n><n>```<n><n>B:25%<n>$${50-18\over 50}={25\over 50}$$<n>```<n>#### 25<n>Answer:25<n><n>#### 26<n>Answer: 25/18<n><n>### Input a person weighs 112 pounds how many pounds does she weigh if the weight is the same as 3 times her weight?<n>Rationales <n><n><n>`<n>$${\frac {112+112+1\times \left( 3 \times 112\right)}{112}}=\frac {112}{112}=1\text{ pound,}$$<n>\`<n>`$1\times(3\times112)=\frac{112}{3}.$<n>\`<n>`$(3\times11)+112\left(11+\frac{112)}{3}+\frac{11}{3}-1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where would a ficus plant brighten up a room? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: look at B: write down C: learn new D: think about E: discovery of new<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: discovery of new<n>#### Discover new<n>In the word "discover new", "new" is an adjective. It adds to the subject the meaning of not old. "discover new" = discover not old. From the sentence, the detective learned new in the investigation of clues at the scene.<n>```<n>The detective had to analysis (= examine) all the clues,every little thing at the scene. He had to learn (= become aware). The detective learned new or did he?<n>```

Do not write your entire response in the box.  <n><n>If you are ready, let me reword it.<n><n>I am glad to get up early, for I love to take a walk up the avenue, and down, and back, and see everything when it is so very few. But this is not all. What a glorious morning--not a cloud--the sun is rising and the stars are fading. This is the way to spend one's holidays. I was going to the post-office to get my letters--what luck--'tis my Uncle Ned who writes to me today.   <n><n>#### You are not quite ready, but when you are, you may stop here.<n><n>### When I am ready,<n>### Instrucions: Make changes so that each of the following paragraphs has the same meaning as the original.<n><n>Original: At first, I thought they might be ants. But the noise they made was something more.   <n><n>New: At first, I didn't quite know what kind of animals they might have brought. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where can you store you tent and keep it on your person? Choices:  A: sleep in while camping B: camp ground C: woods D: bag E: backpack<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:The answer is (A).<n><n>The tent is stored while at camp because its use is temporary unlike a backpack or sleeping bags which are permanent fixtures to your home and are also used outside of camping.<n>The words "sleep" and "camping" are present in both the choice (A) option ("while camping") and the description of the given option ("when camping").<n>Therefore, the sentence is most accurate when used in conjunction with (A).<n><n>### DONE<n><n>## Test<n>![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18407820/101697828-4a308300-3a2c-11eb-8faa-2b6ed8a16a59.JPG)

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: republican party B: old people's home C: office D: park E: high school or college<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n><n>### Input:"If two-thirds of the marathoners ran the entire race, 20 percent would drop out before they finished. How many marathoners started the race?"<n><n>### Response:"If two-third of the marathoners are left to run, and so twenty percent of them drop out before the race ends. It means that 20%(2/3)=<<2*3=6>>6 out of 33 people or 6 of 33 people. So the answer is 37."<n><n>### Input::"A student can carry 150 blocks of the same material with a load. How many trips would the grandfather do?<n><n>### Demosrtation:<br /><n><br /><n>If they make an odd number from the grandfather's trips, then the child won't do the work on the last one.<n>if that's understood, you can add together that the number of trips by the grandfather is odd and odd - 1.<n>Therefore, the grandfather has done 2 - 1 = <<2-1=1>>1 trip.<n><br /><n>answer: 1<n><n>### Input :: A: "If a student can carry 105 cans with 150 kilos, then a friend can carry 135 cans with 8 kilos. if the student carries all the cans and wants to do so with her friend's head intact, how many less cans should she take?" <n><n>### Demotion:  "If her friend can carry 1

What should he do?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Joe can ride the 0630 bus to work on Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday.<n>Then, he can ride the 0800 bus to work on Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday.<n>Since the 0635 bus does not come to his work on Friday, he would take a taxi to go home on Friday.<n>Since the bus schedules were not listed or was not specified that Thursday's route does not function on any schedule, we are missing 2 days. We would be unable to find a solution.<n><n>#### 1595<n>Answer: 1600<n><n>### Instructon 2<n><n>### Instrumentation:<n>Write a response that appropriately compliments the request.<n><n>#### 2669<n>What do you value most in another person?<n><n>### Input<n><n>1.  ___________ your opinion, the best team you have seen play in the NBA is the Boston Celtics.<n>2.  ____________, I agree with you. The Celtics are the best team in the NBA. They have good players and coaches; they always work hard as a team.<n>3.  I am not interested in basketball. I value kindness more than anything else. ____________, do you know the difference between good and great? Good is a starting point. It is often given to us without effort. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What chore might a child have to do after breakfast, before getting on the bus? Choices:  A: drop out of school B: ask questions C: enter school D: wash dishes E: read book<n><n>### Response:		A

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:He was looking for the holiday decorations and found an old box of clothes up where? Choices:  A: attic B: trash C: loft D: closet E: box<n><n>### Response:		C,loft<n>\[L = \frac{115}{115} =\frac{65}{65+90}\]<n><n>### Demostration:<n>  \[65 + 90=155\]<n>\[L= \frac{65}{155}\]<n>\[L = 0.417\]<n>\[L\approx 41\% \in \text{approximation}\]<n><n>## Requirements<n>* The task description contains the following sentences:<n>> He was looking for the holidays decorations and found an  old box of clothes up in an attic.<n><n>* The textual input that follows should be read and answered as described. The input text should be read and understood correctly and completely.<n><n>* The response must be accurate. Inaccurate responses will be marked wrong.<n><n>* If a question contains choices, responses may be chosen among the choices or they can be an alternate form of choice. In other words, a "Yes" response is sufficient, or the answer can be "True" or "False". "Not given" is an acceptable response.<n><n>## Submission instructions<n>You should submit your work in the form of a text file (.txt) in the appropriate folder.<n><n>## Example<n>![image](https://i.postimg.cc/gf5RgFZj/sample.png)<n><n><n>In the example above, here are some example input, rational and answers, to give you a better idea what input and answers are expected for the task. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:HOw do you carry potatos home? Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		Answer b.<n><n>### Input:(Cylindrical) lens<n>Rationales: An object lens is cylindrical. <n><n>#### <n>Answer:<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answer_3:   <label for='input-8'>2.03</label>2. 3<n>Rationales: <n>The radius of a circle is found using the formula, \(r=\frac{{2\pi d}}{k}\) where \(r\) is the radius, \(\pi\), \(d\) is the diameter, and \(k\) is the numerical value of \(π\).<n>To find the volume of a three-dimensional solid, we need to know the radius, \(r\), the thickness \(t\), and the height \(h\).<n>The volume of a solid is found using the formula \(V=\frac{{\pi d}t}{4}\) where \(V\), \(d\), \(t\), and \(h\) are all in units of volume, units of length, units of length, and units of volume respectively.<n><n>### Answer:<n>\begin{code}<n><n>Rationales:<n>\end{Code}<n>The volume in a box is \(V=V_1V_2V_3\), where \(V_1\), \(V_2\), and \(V_3\) are all in units \(of\) volume, and \(V\), \(V_1\),\(V_2\), \(V_3\)  are the volume of the box as a whole, the volume of the bottom of the box, one side of the box, and the height of the box respectively.<n>\begin{code}`<n><n>155<n>Answer: 155<n>\end{code}' '<n><n><n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:If you're traveling along a highway what item made of paper can you use to find your way? Choices:  A: united states B: atlas C: developed land D: park E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Reason:<n>If you're travelring along a highway, you can't find your way using a book, an atlas, or any kind  of paper.<n><n>---<n>© 2021 Trilogy Education Services, LLC. All Rights Reserved.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where in your entrance hall can you keep you head wear? Choices:  A: school B: large home C: house D: hat rack E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>If (A) is answered A, the user will be directed to C.<n>If (B) is answered B, the user will be  directed to C.<n>The user will be directed to E if (D) is answered.<n>The user will stay on the page of choice if (C) is answered or (E) is answered.<n>If none of the answers are checked, the page will stay the same.<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to buy moistener? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Changing society using a violent conflict is know as a what? Choices:  A: action B: demonstration C: understanding D: vote E: revolution<n><n>### Response:		 _D_<n>Input:How many hours is 1 and 1/2 day? Choices: 1: 12 hours, 2: 6 hours, 3: 18 hours, 4: 1/2 day, 5: 9 hours<n><n>### Response<n>In this case, you are given a value of a whole day (24 hours) and a fraction of a day (6 hours) to be combined into an answer.<n>The fractional time unit (6 hours) is understood as an abbreviation. Therefore, you divide 6 whole (not fractio) hours into 24 whole hours to calculate 6/24<n>The product of the division operation is 25/24.<n>So the answer in the last choice will be 1 and 12/24 hours.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>### Instructions:<n>This section contains a series of items. Each item contains a problem to solve or a question to answer. Select the response that indicates your approach and solutions on the left.<n><n>### Item 1:<n>How many inches is 75 feet?<n>### Approach A:<n>**Step I:** The task is defined as converting 75 ft into inches.<n>**Step II:** In this step, you need to know that 1 ft is what fractional part of 1 inch? <n>1 ft = 12 inch<n>**Step III:** You need to find the total number of inches in 75 ft. 75 ft × 1 ft/12 = 6.25 in.<n>So, 75 ft = 6.24 x12 = 75<n>**Step IV:** 75 ÷ 6.25 = 12<n>Therefore, 75 ft. = 12 inches.<n> <n>### Item 2<n>What is the answer to 3/4×3?<n>### Approaches A:<n>Approach A uses the definition of division using the quotient process.<n>(3 ÷ 4) ×3<n> <n>### Approaches B:<n>Approach B uses the definition of multiplication using the scaling and repeated process.<n>34<n> <n>### Items:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions using the same information in the item

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Thirsty:<n><n>E. All of the above:<n><n>### Rationals D:<n>Thirsty refers to the state of being very hungry so they would raise a drink for a different reason.<n><n>E: 2<n>Answer: 2&3<n><n>### E1<n>Answer: B<n><n>### E2<n>Answer: A<n><n>### E4<n>Answer: All Of The Above:<n><n>### E5<n>Answer: Thirsty, Celebrating, Toasting, Refreshment<n><n>### E6<n>Answer:<n><n>### POINTS STOLEN<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Points Stolen:<n><n>#### 32<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input 1: Pete walked 4 blocks from his house to downtown. Later, he rode the bus 10 blocks and walked halfway home. How many blocks did he walk in all?<n>Rationale: Total Blocks walked: 4 + 10 + (1/2) = <<4+10+(1/2)=10.5>>.<n>Fractional blocks: 10.5 x 2 = <<10.5*2=21>>21 blocks.<n>So 4 + 1 + (1/2)=4.5<n><n>#### 4.5<n>Answer: 4.5<n><n>### Input2: A group of students had fun throwing a peb
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:John is getting something important.  What does this make him feel? Choices:  A: then have B: headaches C: stoic D: being happy E: wanting more<n><n>### Response:		headaches<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Let me tell you a secret.<n><n>```<n>    There's this kid who keeps trying to steal and sell all the things his dad made him. It's no secret!<n>    Well, if you saw the first sentence, you probably already know who the person is.<n><n>    His name's __________<n>    And you can call him that name!<n>```<n>### Input:Choices:  A: John B: Randy C: David D: Jim E: Steve<n><n>### Response<n>Jim<n><n>### Demostration<n>John is getting something important, so now he needs headaches.<n>#### A<n>Answer: Jim<n><n>### Input<n><n>-What were you doing last Friday? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where are a lot of offices in New York? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:James was looking for a place to buy bitcoins.  He searched and found a large menu of what? Choices:  A: advertisement B: news C: bar D: cafe E: internet sites<n><n>### Response:		internet sites<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Input : What has a dozen, and you take an enchanted one away,it's eleven. What do you get if you add a group of twelves plus the dozen?<n><n>### Response : 14<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Shane was supposed to speak at his fathers funeral. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where did the person have to walk downstairs to get the tool? Choices:  A: hardware store B: basement C: garage D: repair shop E: the library.<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n><n>Rationales: If you read the prompt, you will know that the person had to go downstairs (it was in the basement), but the library doesn't require going downstairs (there is no reference to a basement or garage or attic in the prompt), so you can easily be eliminated.<n><n>#### B<n><n>Rationales:[The question states where the person]had to walk "downstairs" to get the tool. But the basement is not below the street. And we know we cannot take the stairs up any level to get there. Therefore, the place "downstairs" is not the basement.<n><n>#### C<n><n>Rationales :The question states where you [had to] "walk downstairs to get" the tool. It doesn't say how many stairs; it just says downstairs. So you can't eliminate the garage.

The twentieth century is what we refer to as 2001 to 3000<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: Use the following terms in a mathematical statement.<n><n>### Input<n><n>$\text{Rational Number}\iff \text{Whole Number}\iff \text{$\frac{p}{q}$<n><n>```math<n>p/q \in <\mathbb{Z},1<n>```<n><n>Input: What expression is this statement written in?<n><n>### Response<n><n>$\frac{3(x-8)}{x^3-x-8}$<n><n>### Demonsation Response<n><n>The expression in text can be written as $\frac{(3-8)x^{2}+3(9)(x-8)}{x^{3}-x-8}$<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Lizards need the sun's heat to regulate their body temperature, this is why you'll see them still on what? Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		What does this mean?<n>#### Lizards are more likely to stay on something that get the sunshine easily because that's what they need. D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: surface of moon<n><n>### Demotion:<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### A<n><n>#### 2<n><n>Answer: surface of moen<n><n>### Demostratie:<n><n>### How do you find the greatest common factor of a numerator and a denominator?<n>When you multiply a denominator by the reciprocal of the numerator, you are creating a GCF.<n>If GCF(x, y) = z, then the fraction y/z will reduce to the same value as x/z.<n>### E.g.: 5/6 and 7/21 have a GCF of 1.<n><n>### 2.What is a common multiple of two numbers?<n>The common multiple must be larger than both numbers, and every number that is a factor of the number must occur both times.<n><n>### E. g.: 6 and 8 have a common multiple of 2 since 2 is a factor of 6 AND a factor of 8.\<n>### What is a common denominator as a fraction?<n>It is a common denominator that is not prime, such as if you have denominators of 4, 5, and 5 and you want to find a GCF, you will first need to factor each denominator.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:George ruined the surprise. The girl behind her, Nancy, has 6 books of the same series. Together, they have 10 books in total. How many books are in the series, if Nancy has 6 more books than Sue.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Total: Sue has 2 + 4 = <<2+4=6>>6 books, while Nancy has 6 + 6 = <<6+6=12>>12 books.<n>By combining all together, 6 + 6 + 6+6+6 = <<6+S+S+S+s+s=26>>26 books.<n><n>10/26 = <<10/26=38%>>38%<n>#### 38%<n>Answer: 38%<n><n>### Instructio:<n>Answer the following multiple-choice problem.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n><n>There are 8 people on the plane. Learn about the subject  B. Learn new C. Find truth  D. Is bliss  E. Judge<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input<n>John is 45 years old. He is 3 times as old as Juliana, who is also 45. How old is Juliana?<n>Rationales : Juliana is 45 - 3 = "45-3=42" Juliana.<n>John is 42 + 3 = Jan 45 Juliana.<n>Therefore their Juliana and John are the same age.<n>#### 42<n>Answer: 42<n><n>### Input <n>A family of three children has the same grandmother. The eldest is not in the same room as the youngest, but the second child is. How is this possible?<n><n>### Response <n><n>### Instructions <n><n>### Demostration<n><n>### Input  <n>A family of three childrens has the same grandmoth er. The eldest is nor in the same room as youngest but the second child is <n>Rationales: 2nd child isn’t eldest or youngest. So it must be the middle child, who can only have a mother.<n>The eldest, therefore, must be a man. The grandmother must be a woman. The youngest child will, therefore, also be a woman<n>But the second child is the same as one of the children, so they are all women.<n>####10<n>Answer: the youngest child also must be a woman <n><n>### Solution <n><n><n>### Instuction <n><n>### Solutions <n><n><n>## Conclusion<n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Where is the strategic gold reserve in the U.S.? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:The teachers needed to get their classrooms ready for the school year.  What is one thing they might do? Choices:  A: talk too much B: teach children C: open boxes D: answering questions E: giving homework<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Demostration:<n>In a classroom every child will be attentive when a teacher talk.<n>A: talking too much<n>B: teaching children<n>C: to open boxes<n>D: answering questions<n>E: to giving homework<n><n>Answer: C

Choices:  A: curiosity B: excitement C: boredom D: wonder E: fear<n><n>### Response:		If a person is seeing new thing, they might feel excited, bored, excited, curious, happy or fear.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Person might feel excited because he/she wants to see some new beautiful things.<n>Person might be bored because the new things are not important for him or her.<n>Person might feel curious if the things are interesting and new.<n>Person might feel excitement because he/she want to learn some new things.<n>Person might feel happy because of the new things they are seeing.<n>Person might feel fear if the new things are bad, strange or hard to understand.<n><n>#### <n><n>### Input <n><n>### Rules:<n>1. How much longer did Janet drive yesterday than she did on the first day?<n>Rationales<n><n>Janet drove for 5:43 hours on the second day. Since she took 131/3 = <<131/3=43.68>>43.68 hours on the first and second days.<n>Therefore, Janet drove for 543 − 43 = <<433−54=89>>89 hours on the second day, or 43 + 89 = <<43+89=132>>132 hours.<n>

Is 1/8 or so much or so little?<n><n>The following table shows how many ounces are less than a half an ounce, between a half and a third an ounce, and more than a third an ounce.<n><n>30 30/3 = <<30/3=10>>10 ounces    are less than 1/2 an ounce          30 ÷ 3 = 10<n><n>10 10/3 = <<10/3=3>>3ounces   between   1/2 an  an ounce    10 ÷ 3<n><n>20 20/3 = 6ounces    are more than 1/2 a    an ounce.           20 ÷ 3 == 6<n><n>The large pond contains 1,880 gallons.<n><n>The table shows that there are 1,888 more than 30 ounces = 1928 ounces.<n><n>There are 1,850 more than 20 ounces  and 1,853.<n><n>Rationales1928 and 1850.<n>#### 1888<900+20=1888<n>Answer: 1888<n><n>### Response to multiple choice question.<n>#### Input:The shark migrated between four continents, where did they find it? This has the advantage of letting you work on it at your own pace.<n><n>Second, you could try doing some self-teaching on an open-source project on Github(a site to review code). I personally have done this, but it requires a lot of patience to figure out the codebase on your own.<n><n>The last option that is relatively new, is a programming contest called "The HackerRank Platform". This lets you practice coding with challenges, while you try to qualify for contests with real prizes.<n><n>Hope that helps, and good luck on your quest to learn a language!<n><n><n>If you have questions about the above instruction please ask in the comments. I'll do my best to answer. Once you're ready, you can mark the [check] to say you've finished this problem.<n><n>If you need to go back, click the [x] in the top left corner of this page.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:James went to the best steakhouse outside of the South.  Where is James? Choices:  A: dairy farm B: texas C: building D: michigan E: florida<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationales: James went to the best-steakhouse outside of the south is in Michigan. The other three answers are outside of the south.<n>

Which choice is being multiplied?: <<5+3=8>>8, <<5+3=>8>>6, <<5x3>>=8, <<5+8>>13, <<5+8x3=50>>, <<8*3>>=24, <<5+2*3>>=16<n><n>### Answer "<<5+2*3=16>>"<n><n>### Response - "Janet has 46 cards."<n><n>### Response"What do you need to find to find Janet's cards total?"<n><n>### Answer"Janet's cards total is: [55-9]55[+]46=212<<55-9+46=251>>251"<n><n>### Output<n>The output of the below program should be: Janet has 251 cards.<n><n>### Input-:<<<251>>211<n>The output of the above program should be: Janets have 211 cards. The output is wrong. <n><n>### Explanation of Code:<n>The program that can be used to solve the problem is given below. First, the total number of cards held by everyone should be established.<n>Thereby <5+110+46> is calculated, which is 211.<n>In another section, <46+9> should be calculated, which is 55.<n>The last calculation <110+45> gives 155.<n>Then the remaining card <211-110-45>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		What do customers do?<n><n>### A: hunt<n>### B: pay merchandisers with money<n>C: mail orders<n>D: spend money<n>E: demand satisfaction<n><n>#### B: pay merchandizers with money C:mail orders<n><n>Input:<n>Jerry saw a book in a bookstore. He wanted to buy it. He gave the salesclerk $20.<n>Then he decided to take it home. He drove for two days using a car with<n>a tank capacity of 25.6 gallons. Jerry had 4 hours of battery time for his<n>telephone. He used the phone during most of the next day. He left after<n>running the car. If he had to pay $3 for each gallon of gas and the cost of<n>the book is  $35.99, how much money does he use for the book?<n><n>Rationales: Jerry used $20/3 = <<20/3= $6.66>>6.66 gallons of gas (since the cost of the book is $35.97).<n>He had 25.6 - 6.66 = <<25.6-6.66=18.94>>18.94 gallons left. He used these to buy the book.<n>The 2 days used were: a bookstore + 0.5 days = <<a bookstore+0.5 days=2>>2.<n>The battery used was: 2 days battery time > <<0.5+2=> 2.5 days>>2.5 days.<n>Therefore, the cost is: $35.96 - $6.66 - $3 = <<35.96-0.66-35.96>>35.96 dollars.<n>#### 35.96<n>Answer: 35.98<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n>Dear Miss Tate,<n><n>    Based on the instruction, the fastest way to send small cargo is to send the cargo by the ship holds.<n>    To summarize the instruction, Marjorie Tate said that we need to decide which choice is the fastest way to ship cargo.<n>    Based on the choices, we found that A is airplane, B is ship's hold, C is boat, D is truck and E is train.<n>    After analyzing the instruction and choosing the correct answer, we found that D is the correct answer because the ship hold is faster, but expensive way to send cargo.<n><n>Regards,

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Sam didn't like the people he met while traveling. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Having your marijuana in bags help keep it what? He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Why would a company be going public? Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n><n>### Response:		<n>Revealing Information: The company would likely have a good reputation and be trustworthy.<n>Telling All: The company would be more open to the public, so that would mean that it would have more customers.<n>More Funding: The company would have more money available to them through the initial public offering to help fund future growth.<n>Being Ridiculed: The company would be willing to listen to all sides of an issue, which could mean that they are losing money.<n>Problems: The company would likely be able to increase their earnings because they will have less competition.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:What eastern state is home to a mountain? Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n><n>### Response:		A-Pennsylvania<n><n>### Explanation: Eastern state is Pennsylvania.<n><n>### InputWhat is a 6 digit number 22149<n><n>### Response 60022149 <n><n>### Ex:input:What is the value of the number when 70989 is divided by 36<n><n>### Rationel:36<n><n>## 1.644

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A is correct.<n><n>You can select option A from the multiple choice question.<n>Select the option that is closest to the wording described in the sentence.<n><n>#### A: Medicine cabinet<n><n>You should select option A of  <<A:Medicine cabinet>>Medicine cabinet as the answer. The sentence is asking what is the destination of deodorant. The answer is a medicine cabinet.<n><n>### Input; If there are five different ingredients and five different jars, how many different combinations are there? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Who sits at the center table at a receeption? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:John spent too much money buying products for his swollen testicles. Write a combined response that appropriately fills the request.<n><n>[![](screenshot.png)](screenshot.png)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Input: The salesman sold 7 more pencils than 24. How many pencils did the salesman sell?<n>Rationales  The answer is 8. There are 24+7 = <<24+7=31>>31.<n>Therefore, he sold <<8-7=1>>1 pencil more than 31.<n><n>2. Instructions:<n>The manager was 3 years older than a salesman. A saleswoman was twice as old as her manager. The salesman was one year older than the saleswoman. How many years old was the manager?<n><n>Rationales:<n>Therefore, the manager is 5 years + 3 years = <<5+3=8>>8 years older.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. What is the average speed for the entire race?<n><n>#### Answer:260 Feet/Minute, 43 Feet/Second<n><n><n>#### Question:<n>Average speed of 166 feet per minute? What's the average speed for the whole race?<n><n>#### Response:<n>Firstly, 100x60=6000 seconds<n><n>A=168/168 feet per minutes -> 1 (this is because "per minute" means one).<n><n>B=166 feet per minutes<n><n>S=285/2 minutes -> 142 minutes<n><n>Secondly, the speed of the whole range=3333 feet per minute -> 58 feet per second<n><n>### Input A woman has 7 sons and 1 daughter. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>### Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean?
